A 30-year-old man was shot in the head around 2:10 A.M. yesterday in front of the Foo Joy restaurant at 13 Division Street, in Chinatown, the police said. He was identified as Wong Hing Chung of 883 Third Avenue. He was taken to Bellevue Hospital in critical condition.

DETROIT, Dec. 11 (AP) BMW of North America Inc. said today that it was increasing list prices of its 1980 cars by an average of 9 percent. John A. Cook, president, said BMW expected to increase sales of the German-made cars by 7 percent to about 37,500 in 1980.

PARIS, Dec. 11 Saudi Arabia, the world's richest oil-exporting country, is puzzling Western bankers and monetary officials because it seems to be growing poorer despite recent oil price increases. The country's monetary reserves appear to be steadily declining.

A recent notable innovation in bridge publishing is a series of pamphlets each dealing with an aspect of the game, almost all about bidding. They are primarily the work of Ron Andersen of New York, although other leading figures have contributed their names.
LEADERLESS orchestras are not exactly the newest thing under the sun, but in this age when conductors are arguably the most glamorous figures in the music ...

The American Broadcasting Companies, the Shubert Organization and Robert Altman's Lion's Gate Films yesterday announced the formation of a partnership to make film and video cassettes of theatrical productions.

TABRIZ, Iran, Dec. 11 Supporters of Iran's revolutionary Government rallied here today to back negotiating efforts by an official of the Teheran Government. But the rally ended in scuffling and shouting, with members of the Azerbaijani minority challenging the Teheran authority.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 Energy Department investigators today announced the filing of 13 charges against the Gulf Oil Company and Chevron U.S.A., two major refining companies, accusing them of having overcharged their customers by $550 million between 1973 and 1976.

ROME, Dec. 11 (Reuters) Italian banks today announced a three-point increase to 19.5 percent in their prime lending rates, the interest rate on loans to their most creditworthy borrowers. The increase, effective immediately, follows a three-point increase in the official bank rate last week and reflects a recent upsurge in Italian inflation.

The chief consultant to the labor unions during the city's fiscal crisis sharply criticized the Municipal Assistance Corporation and other fiscal monitors yesterday for continually projecting budget deficits and creating what he said was an atmosphere that might force the city to accept a strike in March by municipal unions.

LOWER ALLOWAYS CREEK, N.J., Dec. 11 The Salem I nuclear generating station will remain shut down for another two weeks and may not generate electricity before the end of the year, spokesmen for the Public Service Electric and Gas Company said today.

The Synagogue Organization of Reform Judaism vowed today to challenge the policy of the Israeli Government that recognizes Orthodox practices as the only official religion and prohibits non-Orthodox rabbis from performing legitimate ceremonies such as weddings, funerals and conversions.

Although summer is generally considered the season of greatest gastronomic bounty, sophisticated palates are more likely to be beguiled by the subtle and luxurious specialties of autumn. Count among those culinary treasures not only game, foie gras and the black truffles of France but also the even more odiferous and pungent white truffles hunted by trained dogs in the Piedmont section of Italy.

The serene countenance of Earline Garland, who was pressed sardine-like yesterday in an IRT Flushing Line subway rocking and rolling toward Manhattan, flew in the face of tradition. It was the second workday of the Long Island Rail Road strike, and, according to transportation officials and the unwritten law of transit walkouts, chaos should have abounded among commuters.

SAN MATEO, Calif., Dec. 11 (AP) Daniel E. Koshland, a former president of Levi Strauss Company who helped to guide the concern in the 1950's and 1960's when blue jeans leaped in popularity around the world, died last night in Mills Memorial Hospital after a long illness. He was 87 years old.

IN order to prove that he hadn't Chosen Sides, he was standing around a salmon mousse on a cold Saturday night in Greenwich Village, after three subways and one anxiety attack, among so many smokers with beards that he might have stumbled upon a road company doing "Exodus": "Behold, the bush burned with fire, and the bush was not consumed" (3:2).
Luciano Pavarotti will give a recital on New Year's Eve at 8 o'clock in Avery Fisher Hall, accompanied by the pianist John Wustman. The Italian ...
Affirmed was named yesterday the winner of the Eclipse Award as the horse of the year, a verdict that opened the spigots of praise for thoroughbred racing's first $2 million purse winner.

A stringent plan to monitor the Board of Education's finances was approved yesterday by Mayor Koch and City Comptroller Harrison J. Goldin. The plan includes a request that the school system absorb a projected school deficit of at least $48 million for the 1980-81 school year.

NEW DELHI, Dec. 11 (Reuters) Bandits killed 12 villagers, including 6 women and 3 children, in what the police today described as an apparent revenge raid on a village in India's northern Uttar Pradesh State. They said the gang was probably seeking to avenge the action of villagers who cut off the hand of a bandit leader when they caught him two years ago.
ROME, Dec. 11 Left-wing terrorists stormed the Business Administration School of the University of Turin today and shot 10 carefully selected victims in the legs at close range.
TABRIZ, Iran, Dec. 11 (UPI) Ayatollah Shariat-Madari warned today that "civil war will take place" if Ayatollah Khomeini "makes mistakes again" in handling the revolt in northwest Iran.
Chateau Bouscaut, one of the few major American-owned wine properties in Bordeaux, apparently will return to French ownership under a sale agreement worked out this week.

OTTAWA, Dec. 11 (Reuters) Canadian retail sales fell a seasonally adjusted 1.2 percent in October to $6.52 billion after a 2.1 percent rise in September, the Canadian statistics office said yesterday. The drop was the first since the 3.6 percent decrease in April.

MANY of our food passions are directly related to our favorite childhood foods: From my earliest memory I have been ad dicted to things that come from the charcuterie: pates, terrines, sausages, and salamis. I believe the reason my region, Burgundy, was well-known for such things is because pork was traditionally plentiful and cheap. Therefore, it was put to as many good uses as chicken.

The Staten Island ferry service will resume tomorrow a five-boat schedule during rush hours, with a boat every 10 minutes Mondays through Fridays from 8 to 8:30 A.M. Manhattan-bound and from 5 to 5:30 P.M. Staten Islandbound.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 In response to reports that he is under investigation by the House ethics committee, Representative Charles H. Wilson denied today that he had accepted kickbacks from his employees or had diverted campaign funds to his personal use.

Tenneco Inc., the diversified energy company based in Houston, will pay about $50 a share in stock, or the equivalent of nearly $760 million, for the Southwestern Life Corporation of Dallas under terms of a tentative agreement announced by both companies yesterday.
PISCATAWAY, N.J., Dec. 11 Rutgers put five men in double figures, topped by Kelvin Troy's 19 points, and gainedits fourth consecutive triumph tonight, an 84-68 victory over Massachusetts.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 In the spirit of the season, President Carter today excused 2.1 million Federal employees from working the day before Christmas, giving them a four-day holiday weekend.

Raymond Shapiro is a man of accomplishment and diversity. He enjoys the theater and a game of chess, the south of France and the shores of Fire Island, playing the violin with friends and scrambling in a mean round of poker.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, Dec. 11 (UPI) At least 11 people died and 45 others were hospitalized for cholera in West Java last week. The newspaper Sinar Harspan quoted a doctor at the regional Cibimbing Hospital today as having said that the 11 people died because they suffered from malnutrition caused by cholera.

Does Congress need a law to hold Congress to spending limits that Congress has already fixed for itself? Representative Robert Giaimo, the chairman of the House Budget Committee, thinks so. Why can't Congress just do what it knows it's supposed to do? Well, says Mr. Giaimo, the new budget controls are breaking down. His point is well taken but the law he offers would only make matters worse.

In the first change of its regulations since the death of the middleweight Willie Classen two weeks ago, the State Athletic Commission began a strict policy yesterday of requiring all boxing promoters in the state to have an ambulance standing by for the professional fights they put on.

I have not yet visited all the people and institutions that fought for my freedom for two and one-half years. If I have not done so in spite of the fact that I left Argentina toward the end of September, it is because I was left bewildered by my first encounters in Tel Aviv, New York and Washington.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 Congressional leaders want to send President Carter an expensive new synthetic fuels bill before Christmas, but they may not have enough legislative shaping days left.

The Mutual Buying Syndicate, one of the oldest and largest independent resident buying offices in New York, is in the process of being sold to a group headed by Irwin Ruben, an outerwear manufacturer, industry sources said yesterday.
MADRID, Dec. 11 (Reuters) A Madrid court has sentenced a woman to 10 years' imprisonment on charges of carrying out abortions, justice sources said today.

The pace of deterioration of apartment buildings in middle-income neighborhoods in New York City accelerated rapidly in the last year and is now faster than in poorer neighborhoods, according to a study of housing code violations to be released today.
Fayette S. Dunn, former president and chairman of the board of the Otis Elevator Company, died yesterday in Dorset, Vt., where he had lived since his retirement. He was 76 years old.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Dec. 11 (Reuters) Bolivians went back to work today after a 24-hour general strike in protest against recent economic measures by the Government of the interim President, Lidia Gueiler. Interior Ministry sources said the situation was normal throughout the country, with the exception of some roads in the central highlands of Oruro and Cochabamba which remained blocked by peasant groups.
CHICAGO, Dec. 11 John B. Connally has decided to forgo Federal matching funds in his bid for the Republican Presidential nomination, according to campaign sources.
THE HAGUE, Dec. 11 (AP) The International Court of Justice today began considering in private session the United States suit against Iran, court officials said.

CHICAGO, Dec. 11 (UPI) A Federal appeals court ruled today that two Croatian nationalists accused of seizing the West German Consulate in 1978 may be retried only on a reduced charge of imprisonment of foreign officials.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 The Carter Administration said today that the first televised interview with a hostage in Iran had added nothing to Americans' knowledge of the situation but might have the effect of heightening world concern about the fate of the 50 captives.

With candlelight and pleasure glowing in their distinguished faces, 14 Americans who had won Nobel Prizes over four decades celebrated Monday's Nobel Day at the Swedish Consulate on Park Avenue. They shared a traditional holiday smorgasbord and memories of warm December welcomes at their own award ceremonies in Stockholm.

The National Theater in Washington has asked the Shubert Organization to take over its management. In what was apparently a nearly unanimous vote, the National Theater's board of directors voted on Monday, according to Maurice Tobin, president of the board, ...

BOXBOROUGH, Mass., Dec. 11 The agricultural commissioners of 10 Northeastern states today announced a regional farm policy intended to help revitalize the area's already reawakening agricultural economy.
The Standard Poor's Corporation said yesterday that it would begin rating certificates of deposit issued by savings and loan associations in the Eurodollar market.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 A Federal district judge today ordered an immediate halt to special immigration checks on the more than 50,000 Iranian students in this country and forbade the Government to use the information it had already gathered from the students.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (UPI) The space agency took the first step today toward developing a spacecraft to rendezvous with Halley's Comet in 1985 by awarding contracts to two aerospace companies for the design of new solar electric rocket engines.

TOKYO, Dec. 11 Japanese officials talked today of possible future cuts in oil imports from Iran, but both they and the nation's newspapers complained that the United States did not understand Japanese needs when it accused the Government here of undercutting American efforts to free the 50 hostages in Teheran.

MEXICO CITY, Dec. 11 Hammer and chisel in hand, President Jose Lopez Portillo stood before a large unsculptured stone titled "Mexico." "Well, what's it going to be?" asked a bedraggled peasant. "That's what I'd like to know," replied the President. And to one side, a rotund businessman in a top hat added quietly, "Me too."
SOUTH BEND, Ind., Dec. 11 The pairing on the marquee outside Notre Dame's arena provided enough buildup tonight for any basketball fanatic: "N.D. vs. U.C.L.A."

People who couldn't believe forecasts of temperatures in the 60's in midDecember ended up carrying their coats on their arms yesterday afternoon when the temperature reached 63 degrees in Manhattan at 2:45. The reading was just short of the record of 64 degrees for the date, set in 1879.

DENVER, Dec. 11 The "unity" leadership of Sam Church Jr., who became president of the troubled United Mine Workers of America barely a month ago, continued to roll today like coal pouring off a conveyor belt.

TEL AVIV, Dec. 11 A dispute has reportedly broken out within the Israeli general staff over a decision to combine all ground forces under a single command and to bring Maj. Gen. Israel Tal out of retirement to head it.
The prices of most major commodities traded on United States futures markets rose yesterday as gold breached $450 an ounce.

SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 11 (AP) Sirhan B. Sirhan, convicted of the 1968 assassination of Senator Robert F. Kennedy, today asked a Federal court to cut his California prison term. On Nov. 8, the state Supreme Court denied a similar request without comment.

TORONTO, Dec. 11 Conrad Black, a 35-year-old "boy wonder" with vast business holdings across Canada, has initiated the first of what is expected to become a scrambled series of controversial bids for control of this country's third-largest newspaper chain.
Wayne Fickinger, who somewhere along the line wandered from the straight and narrow path of journalism, has been named president and chief operating officer of the J. Walter Thompson Company.
The United States Department of Justice charged yesterday that last June's New York City Civil Service examination for new police officers discriminated against black and Hispanic candidates.
Following are emergency measures and services that have been put into effect to help move commuters in and out of New York City during the Long Island Rail Road strike.

The soaring price of gold bullion sent precious metal stocks higher yesterday on Wall Street. Elsewhere, selected oil issues responded affirmatively to results of a test at a well off Newfoundland and, in the takeover sector, a new suitor for Warner Swasey sent that stock sharply ahead.
In restaurants and in hotel rooms, on matchbook covers, napkins and scratch pads, Alex English, an Indiana Pacers forward, often turns to poetry to express his moods.
ATLANTA, Dec. 11 (AP) Bert Lance's co-defendants have abandoned efforts to have their trial on bank fraud charges moved from Atlanta to Rome, Ga. The trial will begin Jan. 14.

A powerful bomb, apparently set by the anti-Castro Omega 7 terrorist group, exploded at the Soviet Mission to the United Nations on East 67th Street last night, injuring four police officers and at least two mission employees and shattering hundreds of windows throughout much of the block beween Lexington and Third Avenues.
The Rangers defeated the Red Wings, 2-1, in Detroit on goals by Don Maloney and Walt Tkaczuk. Article is on page B11.

WASHINGTON, Wednesday, Dec. 12 (AP) Army investigators are expected to tell a House Foreign Affairs subcommittee today that they are convinced, but cannot prove, that Vietnam is using chemical warfare against Laotian mountain tribesmen.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 11 (AP) Following is the roll-call of votes by representatives from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut in the House's decision today to give states the right to decide whether to spend their own Medicaid funds on abortions. A "yes" vote represents a vote in favor of the proposal and a "no" vote represents a vote against it; "xxx" means not voting.

And Maggie Prodo, a single parent who lives in Weston, Conn., with her three children, was just about to put a new tricy cle under the tree for her youngest when she discovered, to her dismay, that "the big box was a mess of jangles I'd forgotten these things don't come assembled anymore."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 President Carter, countering a 3-to-2 recommendation by the International Trade Commission, has decided against imposing quotas on the import of anhydrous ammonia, used mainly in fertilizers, from the Soviet Union.
The American Financial Corporation, the Cincinnati-based financial services company, said yesterday that it had bought 8.3 percent of the shares of Gulf and Western Industries for $74 million.

Celeste Holm will present a onewoman show, "Paris Was Yesterday," based on the book by Janet Flanner, in a limited engagement from Dec. 19 to Jan. 9 at the Harold Clurman Theater, 412 West 42d Street.

Citing official estimates that the Long Island Rail Road strike could increase the demand for gasoline by as much as a million gallons a week, Governor Carey yesterday ordered the immediate release for sale in Nassau and Suffolk Counties and parts of New York City of 1.4 million gallons of the state's December set-aside reserve.

Criticized by both its own journalistic competitors and officials in Government, NBC News yesterday defended as "an important public service" its telecast Monday night of an interview with an American hostage in Teheran under conditions largely controlled by the Iranian student captors.

ALBANY, Dec. 12 Backers of Ronald Reagan for the Republican nomination for President refused today to go along with a plea by New York party leaders to support uncommitted delegates to the national convention.

Dr. James J. Gibson, a professor emeritus of psychology at Cornell University who was known for his studies in the field of perception, died Tuesday at the Tompkins County Hospital in Ithaca, N.Y. He was 75 years old and lived in Ithaca.

The confession of a man accused of pushing a young woman in front of a subway train last June is admissible as evidence, an Acting New York State Supreme Court justice ruled yesterday. The man's lawyer had contended that his client had confessed after being threatened during interrogation.

WASHINGTON, Thursday, Dec. 13 President Carter won a significant victory on the Senate floor yesterday when his supporters turned back an effort to kill a proposed minimum tax on oil producers as part of the "windfall" profits levy.

The dancers of American Ballet Theater have rejected the company's latest offer in a labor dispute that resulted in the company's current lockout of its dancers. Negotiations had resumed Monday between Ballet Theater and its 77 dancers, represented by the American Guild of Musical Artists.

LONDON, Dec. 12 Eleven years ago, when a Labor Party Government appointed Christopher Soames to the prestigious and important position of Ambassador to France, it seemed to many to be a most unlikely choice.

The Cobra, whom many people consider the best baseball player on the planet, is pursuing the winter's work this week with a sore throat and a message: The Pittsburgh Pirates, who thrive on adversity, will not be spoiled by success.
HOUSTON, Dec. 12 (AP) The National Aeronautics and Space Administration said today that 2,937 persons had applied for the 10 to 20 places open for the second class for space shuttle astronauts.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 The Federal Communications Commission, in an effort to increase the variety and availability of services to customers in the field of international data communications, approved several policies today to foster broader industry competition.

ST. LOUIS, Dec. 12 (AP) The Southwest Bank of St. Louis, which often acts before larger institutions, lowered its prime rate today by onequarter point to 15 percent. Southwest, the seventh-largest bank in St. Louis, has assets of $140 million.
A SOLOIST who agrees to appear on the same program with "Le Sacre du Printemps" is either an unwary soul or a remarkably confident artist.

Announcement is expected today of the purchase of a portion of Landauer Associates. Shearson Loeb Rhodes Company is expected to share ownership of the real estate consulting firm with four foreign property consulting companies and a group of Landauer executives.

Thomas R. Vaughan, former president, chairman of the board and chief executive officer of the Freeport Minerals Company of New York, died yesterday at New York Hospital. He was 71 years old and lived in Bronxville, N.Y.

The common stock of GambleSkogmo Inc. shot up 7 , to 36, on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday because of an announcement by the Wickes Corporation of San Diego that it had agreed to acquire Gamble-Skogmo for debentures and nonconvertible notes worth $200 million.

ONE day last October, David Dukes found himself running madly up Broadway. "Beebee-bee-bee, by-by-by-by," he enunciated again and again, ignoring wary reactions from people he passed. Dashing into the Martin Beck Theater on West 45th Street, he practiced bounds and leaps and hung from sprinkler pipes backstage.

SAN DIEGO, Dec. 12 (UPI) The parents of a computer company executive killed in the 1978 crash of a Pacific Southwest Airlines jetliner here were awarded $125,000 today, to be paid by the airline. A Superior Court jury awarded the money to Henry and Doris Burzminski of Edmonton, Alberta, for the death of their son, Ronald Burkley, 34 years old. The crash killed 144 persons.

WASHINGTON, Thursday, Dec. 13 The Energy Department plans to accuse the Mobil Oil Corporation and the Amerada Hess Corporation of having overcharged for petroleum products by a total of more than $1.1 billion from 1973 to 1976.

OAKLAND, Calif., Dec. 12 (AP) A Bay Area Rapid Transit rail car was destroyed by a fire and another was damaged today, sending 11 persons sprinting for safety. There were no injuries reported in the fire, but the damage was estimated at $750,000.

A bottle of Chateau Lafite-Rothschild of the 1803 vintage, the oldest to be put on the auction market in modern times, failed to sell yesterday in a wine auction at Sotheby Parke Bernet Company in London.
ASSUMING a munificent Santa prone to grant even the most extravagant desires, our Christmas audio shopping guide now moves into rarefied precincts. Nothing but the best is this week's motto.

OAKLAND, Calif., Dec. 12 (UPI) A 131-day strike against World Airways has ended with the approval of a new contract by pilots, mechanics, flight attendants and ground crew personnel. The airline's president, Edward J. Daley, said that the company would soon announce schedules, dates and fares for its services, which will include low-cost transcontinental service between Newark and Los Angeles.
BOSTON, Dec. 12 (UPI) American men are smoking less but women are smoking in record numbers and their health is declining, according to the Surgeon General of the United States, Dr. Julius Richmond.
PEKING, Dec. 12 Gang warfare erupted in Peking last summer and one fight involved more than 140 men armed with knives, shovels, metal springs and even homemade guns, the Peking Daily disclosed today.

OXFORD, England, Dec. 12 (Reuters) A United States Air Force F-111 fighter with a crew of two was missing and presumed down in the North Sea, the Air Force reported tonight. The plane, from the 20th Tactical Fighter Wing at the nearby base of Upper Heyford, was on a bombing exercise when it disappeared off the eastern coast of England. The names of the crew were withheld.
Princeton played the kind of patient basketball for which it is noted last night and earned its first victory of the season, beating Fordham, 53-43, at the Rose Hill gymnasium.

MADONNA DI CAMPIGLIO, Italy, Dec. 12 (AP) Ingemar Stenmark, Sweden's ski star, nearly fell on the first run, but recovered and scored his third straight World Cup Victory in the men's giant slalom today.
The Rev. Charles L. Taylor, former head of the American Association of Theological Schools in Dayton, Ohio, died yesterday at the Newton-Wellesley Hospital in Massachusetts. He was 78 years old.
Continental Air Lines announced yesterday that A. L. Feldman, currently president and chief executive officer of Frontier Airlines, would assume these same positions at Continental Feb. 1.

The apparent loss of a newly launched RCA satellite, which has been missing in space since Monday, has created confusion and some panic in the cable-television industry, which was depending on it for a range of national programming.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) The Treasury Department today increased the interest it will pay on many United States savings bonds to 7 percent from 6.5 percent.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 Representative John J. Rhodes, Republican of Arizona, said today that he did not expect to seek another term as minority leader in the next Congress, but he added that he would run for the Speaker's post if the Republicans gained control of the House next year.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) The commandant of the Coast Guard today ordered all personnel boarding recreation boats to wear sidearms to protect themselves from drug smugglers. Adm. John B. Hayes said that he had taken the action because of a sharp rise in the use of small, privately owned boats for transporting illegal drugs.
A 37-year-old woman died of multiple injuries in Kings County Hospital after jumping in front of an IND subway train at the Broadway-East New York station in Brooklyn.

Bounded by Central Park and the Hudson River, West 72d Street embodies what the Upper West Side once was and what it is becoming. Within four blocks there are transient hotels and exclusive apartment houses, discount cosmetics stores and European boutiques. For all their individuality, however, many of the people who live and work there had the same question on their minds recently.

DENVER, Dec. 12 By warning members that the United Mine Workers of America, once the nation's richest union, has nearly run out of money, the miners' new president, Sam Church Jr., today won a 120 percent increase in dues at the union's national convention here.

LOS ANGELES, Dec. 12 (AP) The Mobil Corporation and Texaco Inc. filed suits in Los Angeles Superior Court today in connection with yesterday's $3.65 billion takeover of the Belridge Oil Company by the Shell Oil Company, the largest corporate merger in history.

TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 12--Teheran newspapers and the Teheran radio distributed a letter today that Senator Edward M. Kennedy ostensibly wrote to Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini pledging his support and seeking a meeting. But a Foreign Ministry spokesman later dismissed the letter as a hoax.
HANUKKAH begins tomorrow night, and this year there are notable reinterpretations of the menorah, the traditional candelabrum that is used during the eight-day festival.
Hazel M. Osborne, who was active for many years in social work with children, died last Saturday in New York HospitalCornell Medical Center. She lived in Manhattan and was 75 years old.

BOSTON, Dec. 12 In assessing the Boston Celtics' rejuvenation from a team with a 32-50 won-lost record last season to a club with a 22-7 record, the best in the National Basketball Association this season, there are plenty of factors to point to.
The New York City Health Department yesterday released the names of 31 food establishments that have violated the Health Code.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 John B. Connally, stepping up his attack on Ronald Reagan, challenged the former California Governor to "come out of the closet" to join the Republican Presidential forum in Iowa and accused Mr. Reagan of making "more inflammatory" comments on Iran than Senator Edward M. Kennedy.

PARIS, Dec. 12 (AP) Inflation in the 24 member states of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development rose by 1 percent in October and 11 percent from the yearearlier month, the O.E.C.D. said today.

Max Habernickel Jr., founder and chairman of the Haband Company, which owns the Haband chain of men's clothing stores in northern Jersey and a mailorder house in Paterson, N.J., died Monday at Valley Hospital in Ridgewood. He was 77 years old and lived in Ridgewood.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) For the first time, laboratory tests have revealed traces of dioxin, a dangerous chemical, in men who were exposed to Agent Orange when that defoliant was sprayed in Vietnam, the Veterans Administration said today.

KINNELON, N.J., Dec. 12 Six hundred of Kinnelon High School's 752 students in this wealthy Morris County community voluntarily filed into a temporary crime laboratory set up in the school library today to be fingerprinted.

BOSTON The effort to carry out the next phase of the Camp David agreement has inevitably lost the attention of the public, and of distracted Washington officials, during the Iranian crisis. But the problem is there, and current developments are making it, if anything, more urgent to find a solution.

ALBANY, Dec. 12 Despite the opposition of religious educators, some of whom invoked the Bible to argue their point, a committee of the Board of Regents voted today to prohibit corporal punishment in church-affiliated schools as well as in public schools in the state.

Confronted with evidence of a breakdown in the state's system for disciplining 450,000 licensed professionals, the New York State Board of Regents meets today to begin enacting parts of a major program for change.

An Elizabeth Swados musical, "The Incredible Feeling Show," designed for and performed by children, will open Christmas week at the Beacon Theater, Broadway and 74th Street. It will be limited to 10 performances.
GLENWOOD LANDING, L.I., Dec. 9 The Long Island Rail Road is not running these days, and many Islanders are rearranging their lives to cope with transport.
HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Dec. 12 Marvin Powell was voted by his teammates as the most valuable Jet today.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) The House ethics committee today rejected arguments that Representative Daniel J. Flood was not competent to respond to allegations of financial misconduct, but it voted an indefinite delay in testimony by the Congressman.

Frey, and frequently revised, to keep the struggling Chicago-based company alive by narrowing its horizons, investing in its strengths. That plan, he says, is virtually complete.

TWO prestigious furniture companies, Knoll International and Thonet, have recently opened new showrooms in New York. Traditionally, these spaces are designed as a backdrop for the furniture, but they also serve to convey the design "image" a company wants to project.

TABRIZ, Iran, Dec. 12 In the back of Asghar Binavai's house on Shambayghazan Street, behind the courtyard that contains grape vines and a tiny water tank, there is a small room in which the old man and three of his sons spend nine hours a day weaving carpets. This room is so far from the street that no traffic noise floats in.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Dec. 12 (AP) A series of explosions destroyed parts of a sprawling Japanese-owned oil refining complex on Puerto Rico's southern coast late yesterday, jolting nearby towns and injuring 11 workers. Two were reported in serious or critical condition.
IN her debut as a playwright, the actress Roni Dengel displays a decided ability to create vigorous scenes that delineate the banal ities of suburban life with a vicious wit.

Uta Hagen will return to Broadway in February in "Charlotte," a twocharacter play by Peter Hacks, a West German writer, in which she will play Goethe's mistress. The other character, her husband, will be played by Charles Nelson Reilly, who, however, will speak not a word. Miss Hagen, who has not been on Broadway since 1968, will have them all.

David N. Kershaw, senior vice president of Mathematica Inc. of Princeton, N.J., a social science research organization, died Saturday of cancer at the Morristown (N.J.) Memorial Hospital. He was 37 years old and lived in Hopewell, N.J.

Goldmark Jr., executive director of the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, didn't recognize his mother. SAN ANTONIO, Dec. 12 (UPI) Police officers today dragged five Iranian students screaming "Khomeini! Khomeini! Khomeini!" through the City Hall lobby to a police wagon, ending their three-day sit-in on the building's steps.
SYDNEY, Australia, Dec. 12 Rupert Murdoch today gained control of Ansett Transport Industries, the owner of two television stations, an airline and other interests.

MADRID, Dec. 12 (Reuters) A gasoline bomb yesterday damaged the Madrid office of Amnesty International, the rights group, the police said. No one was injured. An Amnesty spokesman said it was the third attack this year.

BRUSSELS, Dec. 12 (Reuters) The Saudi Arabian oil minister, Sheik Ahmed Zaki Yamani, said today that his country would raise the price of its oil before next Monday's meeting of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries in Caracas, Venezuela.

Explaining the weaknesses it read, "Defensively the Rangers are in a class with such flunkies as Washington and Edmonton."

Dr. Kenneth B. Clark, the psychologist and educator, and Percy E. Sutton, a former Manhattan Borough President, announced yesterday the formation of a survey organization they said would, for the first time, poll the opinions of black Americans nationwide.

Following a considerable expansion of tournament events designed specifically for "newcomers," which means players with fewer than 20 master points, the Greater New York Bridge Association, recently decided to award a trophy to the most successful newcomer each year.

EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Dec. 12 Tom Neville, who rushed off to a hospital last night feeling dizzy, who woke up this morning with his face feeling numb, who has spent the better part of the last 15 years banging his head in National Football League trenches, will start his last game Sunday, just the way he wanted.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., Dec. 11 Like many Long Islanders who commute to New York City, Zachary Fabrizi, a Smithtown resident who works at Federal Plaza in Manhattan, has been up at 5 o'clock these mornings to face the journey to the city without the Long Island Rail Road.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 The House Rules Committee agreed today to schedule floor debate tomorrow on aid to the Chrysler Corporation, but indications were growing that Congress would probably not take final action on the controversial aid package before the Christmas recess.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Dec. 12 United States diplomats here are voicing serious reservations about a trade embargo against Iran.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) The staff of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, using lessons it learned from the Three Mile Island accident last March in Pennsylvania, today outlined a five-year plan to improve safety at atomic power plants.
A group of experts on terrorism suggested yesterday that the taking of American hostages in Iran could be indicative of a new age of terrorism.
PARIS, Dec. 12 (AP)--A "total commitment" to improving facilities appeared today to have saved the 1980 United States Grand Prix East for the Watkins Glen track in upstate New York.
LANSING, Mich., Dec. 12 (AP) Michigan's underground water supplies are threatened by 50,000 sources of potential pollution, some of them dangerous, state environmental experts disclosed today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) The Securities and Exchange Commission today exempted accountants from liability for false and misleading financial information in unaudited business reports.

Once, the United States Olympic Committee was criticized for doing too little in behalf of American athletes. Now, as U.S.O.C. officials begin final preparations for the Winter Olympics at Lake Placid, N.Y., and for next summer's show in Moscow, they are packaging the Olympic logo on everything from Chapstick to Campbell's Soup.

CAIRO, Dec. 12 Sol M. Linowitz, new head of the American team for talks on Palestinian self-rule, brought together the chief Israeli and Egyptian negotiators today and asserted that progress had been made.
SAN FRANCISCO, Dec. 12 A move by Foremost-McKesson Inc. to prevent a takeover by going private has run into a roadblock national economic policy.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia, Dec. 12--This nation returned to legality under the British Crown today when Lord Soames, the man named to guide the transition to black majority rule, arrived to assume his duties as Governor.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) The Interior Department today released regulations that will govern the use of more than 56.6 million acres of Federal land in the West while the Government decides what should eventually happen to the land.
WESTBURY, L.I., Dec. 12 Two young men accused of burning a cross on a black man's lawn in East Meadow last Sept. 3 pleaded guilty in Federal District Court here today.
WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 The Laotians call it "the yellow rain." It struck four times during the month of February, 1978, killing and sickening hundreds of Hmong tribesmen near Xiangkhoang.

NEW ORLEANS, Dec. 9 As his campaign plane sliced through the night toward a strobe-lighted runway, Representative David C. Treen twisted his hands in an uncharacteristic display of nerves. "This is the last flight of the campaign," he said. "If I get killed, Louis Lambert will be Governor."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 Representative Lionel Van Deerlin, Democrat of California, chairman of the House Subcommittee on Communications, plans to unveil a new bill tomorrow to promote competition in the domestic telephone and data communications industry, his staff said today.
IN a season of bloated novels and tired-out talents, what relief to come upon two writers who are challenged by the "fragile" form of the short story.
THE apparent transformation of Hall and Oates from a white soul-disco act in a club band with a rock-and-roll sound would seem to be one of the more surprising pop-music events of the year.

Gold closed at $449.50 an ounce in New York yesterday, down from Tuesday's record price of $451 an ounce, the Republic National Bank said. Earlier, it hit a record $453 an ounce, but it declined amid speculation that the United States Treasury might sell some more of its gold reserves in an effort to deflate the price.

PITTSBURGH, Dec 12 The New York Islanders stole a point tonight. Outplayed for nearly 45 minutes by the Pittsburgh Penguins, showing signs of fatigue and not able to get more than 10 shots in two periods, they came back to score two goals and salvage a 3-3 tie.

A PAIR of friendly tigers, together with a parrot, a monkey and a giraffe, watch over 5-year-old Gideon Brown and his 14-month-old brother, Daniel, in their Upper West Side nursery, while across Central Park the Upper East Side bedroom of 2-year-old Bevin Kaplan is guarded by chipmunks, squirrels, blue birds, lady bugs and one owl.

MOSCOW, Dec. 12 (Reuters) President Jose Eduardo dos Santos of Angola will visit the Soviet Union later this month, the Communist Party newspaper Pravda said today. It will be his first visit since he succeeded Agostinho Neto, who died in a Soviet hospital on Sept. 10.
The New York metropolitan area basked in yet another day of unseasonably warm weather yesterday as temperatures rose to 65 degrees, just three shy of the record for the date, set in 1933.

Is the honeymoon over for human rights in Haiti? Although the regime of President-for-Life Jean-Claude Duvalier should never be mistaken for a democracy, it was starting to move away from the worst practices associated with the rule of his father, the notorious Francois Duvalier, "Papa Doc."

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 Anthony M. Solomon, Under Secretary of the Treasury for Monetary Affairs, reported today that prices being paid for oil from all sources were now more than 80 percent higher than a year earlier.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 President Carter, apparently in an effort to build broader Senate support for the treaty to limit strategic arms, today proposed a five-year increase in the military budget of 4.5 percent a year.

TOKYO, Dec. 12 (AP) North Korea said today it had recovered the body of a United States soldier who strayed into the Communist side of the demilitarized zone and would return it to the United Nations Command, the official North Korean press agency reported.

ATLANTA, Dec. 12 Although Bill Cartwright had a game-high 29 points and 14 rebounds, and Joe C. Meriweather blocked 10 Atlanta shots, the New York Knicks still could not stop the Hawks tonight in the Omni. With free-throw shooting playing a key role in the outcome, the Hawks rolled to their 19th victory in 32 games, 114-102.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 A broad alliance of consumer, labor, religious and environmental groups contended today that there was a growing abuse of power by big business. The alliance called for legislation to set Federal standards of behavior for large corporations.

QUM, Iran, Dec. 12 (UPI) Iran's most powerful revolutionary judge said today that none of the 50 American hostages would be sentenced to death.

Laz Barrera and Laffit Pincay, the trainer and the regular rider of Affirmed, were named winners yesterday of the Eclipse Awards for outstanding trainer and jockey.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Dec. 12 (AP) A Federal district judge refused today to delay the execution of Joseph Carl Shaw, a murderer who is scheduled to be electrocuted Friday.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 The latest Gallup Poll has snatched from Senator Edward M. Kennedy the most compelling argument he had for his challenge to President Carter; the strong appearance so early in the campaign that he had a much better chance than Mr. Carter to defeat the Republicans in a general election.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 The United States withheld its decision today on lifting sanctions against Rhodesia while specialists reviewed the legal and political problems involved. But high-ranking Administration officials said they expected President Carter to announce his decision by the weekend.

MOSCOW, Dec. 12 A Soviet commentator today accused James Reston, the New York Times columnist, of using his reputation to lend credence to the "malicious and nonsensical inventions" of American intelligence in regard to the situation in Cambodia.
BOSTON, Dec. 12 If the New Jersey Nets learned one thing tonight in their 116-102 loss to the Boston Celtics, it was that they have a consistent problem. That problem is inconsistency.

CAPE CANAVERAL, Fla., Dec. 12 (AP) Astronauts and full ground crews will begin the first major simulated flight test of the space shuttle sometime this weekend, according to space agency officials.
PARIS, Dec. 12 (AP) A Paris court today rejected a request by Iran's central bank, Bank Markazi, to order the French branch of Citibank of New York to release $50 million on deposit here.
Bus and subway riders in Queens suffered the heaviest rush hour yesterday since the start of the Long Island Rail Road strike, according to officials of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority.

The police said that the victim, Nelson Albaladejo, 25 years old, a neigborhood resident, had been killed elsewhere and left at the playground, at 141st Street between Alexander and Willis Avenues. The motive was not established immediately.
A contract will be signed shortly for Alexander's Inc. to open in the World Trade Center the first department store in lower Manhattan in decades, according to statements yesterday from both parties.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 12 (AP) President Carter announced today that he was nominating Joseph A. Doyle, a New York City lawyer, to be assistant secretary of the Navy for logistics, manpower and reserve affairs. The Rangers played excellent defense, holding Chicago to 23 shots on goal, as they beat the Black Hawks, 5-2. Article is on Page D22.

West Point-Pepperell Inc., makers of a variety of textiles for the household, apparel and industrial markets, reported yesterday that the company had a 39.2 percent surge in profits for the first fiscal quarter ended Nov. 24 on a sales gain of 21.9 percent.

The credit markets dropped yesterday for the fourth consecutive day, declining sharply in price after the Federal Reserve drained some money temporarily from the banking system. Some short-term interest rates got within a stone's throw of their Oct. 23 highs.

CHICAGO, Dec. 12 Unarco Industries Inc. and Estel N.V., one of Europe's largest steel companies, announced plans today to build a structural steel-tubing mill here with annual capacity of 200,000 tons.

Not only has the 43-year-old Upper West Side food emporium nearly doubled its space in the last week (making the shopping crunch a little less crunchy), but it has also come out with Zabar's Deli Book, a virtual smorgasboard of all the things people love about deli food in general and Zabar's in particular.

The Knicks survived Atlanta's famed pressure defense in the final quarter last night and defeated the Hawks, 101-99, at Madison Square Garden. With gold fever gripping bullion markets abroad, precious-metal stocks produced smart gains on Wall Street yesterday while the general market sagged in heavy trading.

Princess Grace of Monaco, dripping with diamonds and wearing a Dior gown of Christmas red, caused some of New York's most jaded partygoers to act as though they were really enjoying themselves the other night at the Xenon discotheque.

Without a word of complaint, the New York Stars and their coach, Dean Meminger, filed out and began walking.

WASHINGTON, Dec. 21(AP) -- When the American freighter Atlantic Bear slid down the ways in 1976, she was backed by $40.9 million of taxpayers' money. In the following three years, the Bear's owner, Pacific Far East Lines of San Francisco, received $70.3 million of tax funds in subsidies. Today, however, the Bear awaits bankruptcy sale in Virginia's James River.

The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund helps people in a variety of ways. One program started this year focuses on single parents between the ages of 16 and 21. It is the Community Service Society's Adolescent Parent Project in the Red Hook section of Brooklyn.

VINEYARD HAVEN, Mass., Dec. 23-- Martha's Vineyard is threatened with curtailment of ferry service next spring because of a dispute with the Wood's Hole, Martha's Vineyard and Nantucket Steamship Authority over construction of a second ferry slip here. Officials said a reduction of ferry service could mean economic disaster for the island's tourist trade.

VENICE, Dec. 23--Peggy Guggenheim, the expatriate American millionaire who amassed one of the world's foremost collections of modern art, died in a hospital outside Venice today, hospital officials said. She was 81 years old.

TEHERAN, Iran, Dec. 23 -- The 50 American hostages entered their eighth week of captivity today with no indication that their militant captors intended to release them in the foreseeable future.

Darryl F. Zanuck, the last of the flamboyant movie moguls, died of pneumonia late Saturday in Palm Springs (Calif.) Hospital. He was 77 years old. A Hollywood wonder boy at 25, Mr. Zanuck went on to become one of the pacesetters of the film industry, with a career as dramatic as any of the stories he brought to the screen.

SOK SANN, Cambodia, Dec. 21--To get to this village perched atop a steep hill facing the Thai border first requires a 90-minute tractor ride through tapioca fields and jungle. From the foot of the hill it takes another 90 minutes to climb up a trail that crosses five unbridged streams.

They, too, need to be remembered, and helped. Our own holiday would be diminished if we forgot the needy.

Our journalistic problem with Christmas is that it commemorates a colossal triumph of history over news. When Christ was born almost two millenniums ago in a small Jewish town in the Middle East, hardly anyone noticed that something stupendous had happened. Wholesale prices of heating oil in the spot market plunged yesterday to their lowest level in almost a year. Industry analysts said the drop might keep retail prices from rising futher in the months ahead.

WHEN do you need a new mattress? "When you go to bed feeling great and get up feeling lousy," suggested one doctor. A manufacturer said that springs will eventually lose resilience and wear out, creating a "salad bowl" shape that's easy to detect.

DANBURY, Conn., Jan. 9--Citing the "dangerous erosion of free enterprise," the chairman of the Ethan Allen furniture company presented a $600,000 endowment today for a business college "dedi cated to the philosophy that profits, prosperity and social responsibility go hand in hand."

TRENTON, Jan. 9--The State Board of Education today approved two controversial measures setting forth minimum standards for graduation from high school and requiring that each public school receive an evaluation based upon the performance of its students on basicskills tests.

INDULGING in a bit of large-scale musing, an eminent historian recently suggested that our era might be remembered in distant times mainly for two turning points: The first use of nuclear energy and the beginning of recognition of women as legally accredited, full-fledged members of the human community.
DAMASCUS, Syria, Jan. 9 (Reuters)-- President Hafez al-Assad today asked Dr. Abdel Rauf al-Kasm, Governor of Damascus, to form a new cabinet, according to an official announcement.

ALBANY, Jan. 9--With the new legislative session barely under way, leaders in both houses were racing to be the first to pass a bill restoring the death penalty, a politically charged issue in this election year.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (AP)--The Secretary of Education, Shirley M. Hufstedler, named a transition chief today and gave education lobbyists a progress report amid some complaints that she had moved too slowly to fill key posts in her department.

POCAHONTAS, Iowa, Jan. 9--Agriculture Secretary Robert Bergland raced through the cold farmlands of Iowa today, off on a four-day, 23-stop mission to shore up the Carter re-election campaign against farmers' disgruntlement over the limiting of grain sales to the Soviet Union.
J.P. Morgan Company reported yesterday that its net operating earnings in last year's fourth quarter declined by 5.7 percent to $73.2 million from $77.6 million in the year-earlier period.

ATLANTA, Jan. 9--A Federal judge today gave defense attorneys for Bert Lance and three co-defendants until Friday to offer proof that the indicting grand jury had been prejudiced against them by newspaper articles based on alleged leaks from prosecutors, and he said that jury selection in their trial would begin on Monday as scheduled.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (AP)-- Sales of newly built single-family homes plunged by 13.5 percent in November, the sharpest one-month drop in nearly a decade, the Commerce Department reported today.

A Pacific storm pelted the Northwest with freezing rain and snow yesterday, closing schools and highways in Washington and Oregon and virtually paralyzing the Portland area, where 85,000 homes were without electricity.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 9--Representative William S. Moorhead Jr., Democrat of Pennsylvania, announced yesterday that he would not run for re-election when his present term expires in January 1981. Mr. Moorhead, 56 years old, said he planned to return to the practice of law in Washington. He has been in Congress since 1959.
TOKYO, Jan. 9--The bright lights will go off all over Japan at 10 o'clock every night.

Lawrence Schoonover, who left a career in advertising more than 30 years ago to become a successful writer of historical novels. died of a respiratory failure Tuesday in Nassau Hospital. Mineola. He was 73 years old.
The first ad campaign for Pabst Blue Ribbon from McCann-Erickson will be a $2 million magazine effort that breaks next week. Television is promised by-and-by.

The Kansas City Philharmonic has canceled its tour for the 1979-80 season --for budgetary reasons--and will not perform at Carnegie Hall on Jan. 21 as scheduled. Ticket refunds are available at the Carnegie Hall box office.

NEW DELHI, Jan. 9 (AP)--About 100 demonstrators shouting slogans against President Carter rallied outside the United States Embassy here today, protesting American plans to offer arms to Pakistan. The protests were organized by two Indian Communist parties.

SYDNEY, Australia, Jan. 9-- The Australian Government said today that it would support the American ban on grain sales to the Soviet Union by not meeting any resulting shortfall in Russian imports from Australia's ample wheat stocks.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 9 (AP)--Lawyers for Representative Charles H. Wilson, Democrat of California, today asked the House Committee on Standards of Official Conduct to let them inspect all evidence against the Congressman.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 9--Since Kevin Loughery's meeting last season with Commissioner Larry O'Brien of the National Basketball Association concerning Loughery's record of inflammatory arguments with officials, the New Jersey Nets' coach had been on his best behavior this season.

A group of New York City's small municipal agencies are reportedly among those that Mayor Koch is seeking to eliminate as part of his effort to close budget gaps over the next two years.

Volume on the New York Stock Exchange, swelled by the activity of professional and institutional traders, surged yesterday to 65.3 million shares, the third-highest turnover on record. Small retail customers accounted for only a minor proportion of the heavy volume, brokers said.

The general manager of the New Jersey postal facility at which a mail handler was killed three weeks ago in an accident, reigned yesterday, one day after conceding that there were serious safety problems at his facility.

Because of the high prime rate, many people have put off buying a boat in the hope that rates would go down and that the boat would be less costly to purchase. Unfortunately, the total cost of buying a new boat will continue to rise, no matter what happens to interest rates.
THUS far, the rewards that Dudley Moore has received for his widely acclaimed starring role in "10" have been, in a manner of speaking, negative.

Mayor Koch's budget planners, in proposing that 40 of the city's 1,000 public schools be shut down in the 1981 fiscal year, have suggested 10 schools in Manhattan, 10 in the Bronx, 14 in Brooklyn and six in Queens, it was disclosed yesterday.

MOSCOW, Jan. 10--The Soviet decision to move troops into Afghanistan has raised the question of whether the Kremlin leadership has abandoned the policy of detente, a constant during the 15 years Leonid I. Brezhnev has been in power, or whether it miscalculated the reaction the intervention would arouse in the West.

PESHAWAR, Pakistan, Jan. 10--In this ancient dusty trading center just across the Khyber Pass from the Afghanistan frontier, half a dozen exile groups are struggling hard in the campaign to drive the Soviet troops from their homeland.

The Kaiser Aluminum and Chemical Corporation, the nation's third-largest integrated aluminum producer, reported yesterday that its earnings had soared 86.5 percent in the fourth quarter of last year compared with the corresponding period in 1978.

The American military establishment is moving methodically, with no apparent sense of urgency, toward improving its ability to deal with crisis contingencies in the Persian Gulf area and elsewhere in the third world.

Approval of President Carter's handling of the Iranian crisis has dropped since last month, but Americans still approve the President's handling of the situation by a 2-to-1 margin, according to the latest Gallup Poll.
The Securities and Exchange Commission proposed changes in several areas yesterday to reduce the time and expense public corporations face in fulfilling its demands for detailed information.

ALBANY, Jan. 10--Ten years ago this week, Nelson A. Rockefeller stood before the 193d New York State Legislature and, as Governor, spoke of increases--increases in the minimum wage and welfare payments, increases in state aid to... cities, increases in worker's compensation and manpower training programs, increases in aid for community colleges and state university programs, in creases for narcotics abuse programs and staffs for state hospitals.

BERCHTESGADEN, West Germany, Jan. 10 (AP)--Hanni Wenzel of Liechtenstein, mastering icy slopes as other favorites fell, won a pre-Olympic giant slalom today and jumped to first place in the women's World Cup ski standing.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10--In his New Year's Eve broadcast, President Valery Giscard d'Estaing of France said, "There is danger of war. We are living through one of those periods when world balance depends on the level-headedness of a few men..."

MONTREAL, Jan. 10--Quebec's Liberal Party, the major force here opposing this province's proposed independence from Canada, presented voters today with a plan calling for a revision of the federal system to make all provinces sovereign within it.

Bonnie J. Schneider, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Schneider of New York, was married last night to Edward A. Reiss, son of Mrs. Joseph Reiss of East Hampton, L.I., and the late Mr. Reiss. The ceremony was performed at the Carlyle Hotel by Rabbi Harvey M. Tattelbaum of Temple Shaaray Tefila.
Dick Janda, a boatbuilder, may have the answer for the jogger who has wearied of pounding the pavement in polluted, noisy surroundings.

ASWAN, Egypt, Jan. 10--President Anwar el-Sadat of Egypt and Prime Minister Menachem Begin of Israel ended a four-day meeting today with no sign of progress on setting up a self-administering authority for Palestinian Arabs.

HARTFORD IN its time, 1950 on Broadway, T.S. Eliot's "The Cocktail Party" became a cocktail party conundrum, with theatergoers and crit ics wrestling for exegesis. Today, particularly in the Hartford Stage Company's handsome revival, the play seems transparent rather than devious. What survives is the style rather than the content.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., Jan. 10-- Asian nations backing a resolution calling for the withdrawal of Soviet troops from Afghanistan were reported to be confident that they could obtain the twothirds vote needed to pass the resolution as the General Assembly began its emergency debate on the issue today.
IT was impossible not to have had a good time Wednesday night when the Dance Theater of Harlem opened its new season, which runs through Jan. 27 at the City Center55th Street Theater.

BOSTON, Jan. 10--John Williams, the Hollywood composer and conductor best known for the score of such movies as "Star Wars" and "Jaws," was named conductor of the Boston Pops Orchestra today, ending a six-month search that began last year with the death of Arthur Fiedler.

KABUL, Afghanistan, Jan. 10--Soviet military units appear to be concentrating their efforts on securing newly established bases and staging areas, and clearing highways and other land routes west toward Iran, according to Western diplomats and Afghan sources here.

DETROIT, Jan. 10 (AP)--The Ford Motor Company will close its Los Angeles assembly plant permanently next month because of slumping demand for big cars, the company announced today. It will be the second recent closing of an assembly plant, and follows the shutdown by the Chrysler Corporation last week of its Hamtramck, Mich., facility.

Citing a "tight and difficult" budget, School Chancellor Frank J. Macchiarola said yesterday that he questioned a Queens school board's vote to send two members to a San Francisco convention at a cost of $1,500.

This is the story of an uptown party and a downtown party.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10--The Labor Department's Producer Price Index, which measures what retailers pay for the goods they sell to consumers, rose eight-tenths of 1 percent in December, the smallest increase in six months, the Government reported today.

Although most of the major composers have written pieces for the clarinet, a recital devoted to music for the instrument remains a rarity. A clarinetist who has made a place for himself in this unusual area is Richard Stoltzman, who will play a program at Theater in the Park in Flushing Meadow, Queens, on Sunday at 7 P.M.

BOSTON, Jan. 10 (UPI)--Darryl Stingley's attorney, angered by statements in a book by Jack Tatum, asked Commissioner Pete Rozelle of the National Football League today for immediate suspension of the Oakland Raiders' defensive back for an indefinite period.

Gordon Chase, a member of the staff of the White House national security adviser in the Kennedy and Johnson Administrations, was killed in an automobile accident in Weston, Mass., early yesterday. He was 47 years old.

WHILE watching the premiere of NBC-TV's "Live From Studio 8H" Wednesday night, one sort of tele vision buff may have indulged in nostalgia about television's old "Bell Telephone Hour" or the "NBC Opera" series of the 1950's. Another sort, more skeptical, may have marveled once again at the sight of a network trying to compensate partly for sagging ratings with the wooing of some undeniable prestige.

John P. MacKenzie, a staff writer for The Washington Post for 20 years, will join the editorial board of The New York Times next Monday. After leaving The Post in 1976, Mr. MacKenzie, who is 49 years old, spent a year as Walter E. Meyer Visiting Professor of Law at the New York University Law School.

THE appointment of John Williams as conductor of the Boston Pops might seem a risky move by the Boston Symphony management (the Pops is the lightclassical arm of the Symphony). Faced with the nearly impossible task of finding a successor to the charismatic Arthur Fiedler, the Pops has picked a man far better known in a different...

THE hubbub of the holiday season tends to discourage art galleries from opening new exhibitions. The competition for money and attention is too great, and in the midst of so many cultural and social distractions--pleasant and otherwise--what is familiar in art easily triumphs over the unfamiliar. In the first weeks of January, therefore, it seems as if every gallery in town is mounting a new show. Here, then, is a critical sampling from current offerings.

A Manhattan woman, her accountant and their former lawyer were accused yesterday of stealing more than $10 million, most of it from the Small Business Administration and banks in New York and Colorado.

The dollar strengthened in very quiet foreign exchange trading at home and abroad yesterday, but slipped a bit in Tokyo. The price of gold fell in Europe, matching New York gold prices.

WASHINGTON, Jan.10 (AP)--Beatrice N. Vaccara, an acting assistant secretary in the Treasury Department, was named today to head the newly created Bureau of Industrial Economics at the Commerce Department. The new bureau was created as part of President Carter's reorganization of international trade functions to provide information and analysis on the nation's industries.
CARACAS, Venezuela, Jan. 10 (Reuters)--Venezuelan gold output is expected to rise to between 2,500 and 3,000 kilograms this year from 1979's 650 kilograms, gold industry sources said here today.

After he was almost overcome by leaking gas yesterday, a 25-year-old Brooklyn man led two policemen back into the Bedford-Stuyvesant building where he lives, and the three men rescued a woman and three children who had been overcome.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (AP)--A Federal judge today halted destruction of Federal Bureau of Investigation wiretapping records, surveillance logs and other field office files until experts can decide which documents must be retained for their historical value.

Now, the new Cy ColemanChristoper Gore musical, "Atlantic City," is about to become the third big musical to start life in the same unconventional setting--in the record store instead of on the stage. The recording will be made in the spring, after the opening of another new Cy Coleman musical, "Barnum," on April 30 at the St. James.

When there is work for her in the port of Bayonne, N.J., Cookie Escobar rises in the dark of the morning from her bed on the Lower East Side. By 4:30 A.M. she has showered, put the kettle on for tea and unfolded a rickety ironing board. Cookie Escobar is probably the only worker on the New York-New Jersey waterfront who shows up in freshly pressed jeans to load and unload cargo.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (UPI)--Saying it has the Constitution on its side, the Carter Administration asked a judge today to dismiss a lawsuit that seeks a separate 1980 census count of illegal aliens.
TORONTO, Jan. 10--The bidding war for control of Torontobased FP Publications Ltd., one of Canada's top newspaper chains, has heated up again.
A court order forbidding New York City to hire new police officers from the current Civil Service list was overturned yesterday, at least for the time being, by a Federal appeals court in Manhattan.

Katherine Ruth Erskine, daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. William Coventry Erskine of New York and Amagansett, L.I., was married yesterday to George P.T. Ziller, son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen A. Ziller of Leawood, Kan. The Rev. Charles Henderson Jr. performed the ceremony in the Central Presbyterian Church.
The last time Jean Ritchie was back home in Eastern Kentucky, she saw a crawdad--a tiny fresh-water crustacean--in a creek that flows through her land.

MARION, Ill., Jan. 10--Ronald Reagan retreated today from a statement yesterday that he favored "funneling" American arms to forces in Afghanistan that are attempting to resist a Soviet intervention force, in an apparent attempt to allay the impression that he advocated a policy that might lead to a United States-Soviet military confrontation.

The New York State Senate is moving with obscene haste to pass a bill reestablishing the death penalty. That not only cheapens what ought to be one of the most solemn decisions any legislative body can make; the reason for the rush also suggests the incurable weakness of capital punishment.

NAT HORNE brought Dancing Plus to the Theater of the Riverside Church on Wednesday night as the first attrac tion of this winter's Riverside Dance Festival. Dancing Plus is not simply a clever name for Mr. Horne's company, it is a name that suggests what that company is like.

At the age of 67, Gil Evans, who is noted as an arranger and conductor of large jazz ensembles, is making his debut this weekend as a piano soloist. He is appearing tonight and tomorrow, starting at 10:30, at Greene Street--an elegantly converted warehouse at 101 Greene Street that has been in the club business for about a month--in a duo with Lee Konitz, the saxophonist.

On the eve of trial, a Federal judge in Brooklyn yesterday dismissed on technical grounds a five-year-old civil antitrust suit against several major oil companies. They had been accused of conspiring to fix heating oil prices in New York.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10--A Federal grant of more than $100 million was approved today for a Baltimore harbor tunnel, the city's second, to relieve one of the worst traffic bottlenecks on Interstate 95, the Maine-to-Florida artery.

A Dallas group received endorsement yesterday from the National Basketball Association's expansion committee for a franchise starting in the 1980-81 season.

TRENTON, Jan. 10--New Jersey legislative leaders said today that either new taxes or drastic spending cuts would be needed to balance the state budget this year, but they said they could not predict which it would be until Governor Byrne put the finishing touches on his budget message, due next month.

A representative of the Palestine Liberation Organization is aware of the objections and worries evoked by his purchase of an Upper East side town house for $1 million. But the representative, Zehdi Labib Terzi, said yesterday that he expected to win acceptance from his new neighbors.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10--The Carter Administration is seeking the support of Congressional leaders for easing legislative restrictions on covert operations by the Central Intelligence Agency, White House officials said today.

TEHERAN, Iran, Jan. 10 (Reuters) --Iran has proposed a new price of about $3.50 per thousand cubic feet against a previously quoted 75 cents for the gas it sells to the Soviet Union, according to an interview with Iran's oil minister, Ali Akbar Moinfar, in The Iranian, an English-language weekly.

LAST week a band called the Slits made its debut at Hurrah. This is a British new-wave group headed by three women, and while their performance was more interesting for its theatricality than its music, it set one to thinking about two related trends: the proliferation of women's bands or bands led by women, especially in Britain, and the evolution in Britain of a real, artsy, jazzy "new wave" scene to supplant punk.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (Reuters)-- The General Services Administration rejected all bids for gold and silver bullion from Veterans' Administration stocks at its bid opening yesterday, a spokesman said. The agency said it will auction the same material, 256,698 fine ounces of gold bullion and 209,834.76 fine troy ounces of silver bullion, by competitive bids to be opened next Wednesday.
A 26-year-old prison inmate who was knocked out in a boxing bout Wednesday night at the Hartford Civic Center remained in a coma yesterday after undergoing brain surgery.
The credit markets, encouraged by a smaller increase in wholesale prices in December, rose moderately in price yesterday. Short-term interest rates declined quite sharply.
BOWIE, Md., Jan. 10 (AP)--Bowie Race Course will run 10-race programs on Saturdays and Washington's Birthday under a program approved today by the State Racing Commission's Thoroughbred Board.
The stock market forged ahead yesterday with a broad advance in continued heavy trading.

HIGHLIGHTS of the second half of the season, as announced this week by New York's top auction houses, in clude a few glamorous sales from prominent collections, as well as numerous specialty sales. IOWA CITY, Jan. 10 (AP)--Clark Kellogg and Carter Scott combined to hit seven free throws in the final 1 minute 26 seconds to lift Ohio State to a 77-71 victory over Iowa in Big Ten conference basketball game tonight.

TRENTON, Jan. 10--Standards for graduation from New Jersey's publicly owned colleges and universities should put more emphasis on arts and sciences, Chancellor T. Edward Hollander said today. Such emphasis would be in contrast to the current trend toward career training.

BRUSSELS, Jan. 10--Western Europe offered hesitant and incomplete support today for President Carter's plan to cut off United States grain sales to the Soviet Union in retaliation for Moscow's intervention in Afghanistan.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (AP)--Shirley M. Hufstedler, the Secretary of Education, today got her first official glimpse of what is going on in American schools by touring Dunbar High School, once attended by Washington's black elite and now an open-space neighborhood school.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 10 (UPI)-- Officials of the Tennessee Valley Authority, apparently in an effort to avoid a clash with the Federal Nuclear Regulatory Commission, paid a $29,000 fine today for safety violations at the Browns Ferry Nuclear Plant in Alabama. A spokesman said the authority "didn't see any point" in arguing against a fine for what he called "technical violations" at the facility near Athens, Ala.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 10 (UPI)--The District Attorney's Office has filed five more charges against Angelo Buono, already accused of joining his cousin in the so-called hillside strangler slayings in the Los Angeles are in 1977 and 1978. Mr. Buono was previously accused on 27 counts, including first-degree murder, in 10 of the 13 slayings. He has pleaded not guilty to charges that he helped Kenneth Bianchi commit the slayings.

PALM SPRINGS, Calif., Jan. 10 (AP)--Arnold Palmer made a hole-inone, Johnny Miller withdrew from the tournament and Bob Proben, a longshot rookie, survived a shaky finish for a share of the lead today in the first round of the $304,500 Bob Hope Desert Classic.

John Williamson, the New Jersey Nets' guard who has sat out the team's last 15 games because of a weight problem, was reported to have weighed 212 pounds yesterday at a meeting with the Nets' management.

DES MOINES, Jan. 10 (UPI)--Vice President Mondale bitterly denounced Senator Edward M. Kennedy today, saying that his criticism of President Carter's curtailment of grain to the Soviet Union was playing politics with the national interest.
The RCA Corporation announced yesterday that it had licensed its longtime broadcasting and record-industry rival, CBS Inc., to manufacture and distribute SelectaVision videodisk records.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 10 (UPI) --Argentina, a major grain exporter, said today that it would not join Washington's effort to adopt economic sanctions against the Soviet Union, a major trading partner for this Latin American country.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10--President Carter today announced a plan to spend $2 billion more on programs to help unemployed youths prepare for and enter the work market. He termed it a "historic investment" in the future.

St. Clair McKelway Dies; Writer for New Yorker St. Clair McKelway, whose lean prose and ample wit punctuated dozens of articles for The New Yorker for more than three decades, died yesterday at the DeWitt Nursing Home in Manhattan. Mr. McKelway, who was 74 years old, had been in poor health for years and had not written in some time.

Telephone companies in New York State were ordered yesterday to further loosen their grip on equipment by allowing customers to purchase or install their own in-house telephone wiring, which they must now rent for a monthly fee.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10--United States officials who deal regularly with representatives of Cuba said today that they had found the Cubans reluctant to discuss the Soviet move in Afghanistan.

The Diamond Shamrock Corporation, a diversified chemicals and energy company, announced yesterday that its earnings in the fourth quarter of 1979 rose 26.6 percent to $58.5 million, or $1.10 a share, from $46.2 million, or 88 cents a share, in the corresponding period a year ago. Sales rose 40.2 percent to $666 million from $475 million in the year-ago quarter, Diamond Shamrock said.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (AP)--An eight-year ban on movement of poultry and other birds from Puerto Rico to the United States mainland has been lifted, the Agriculture Department said today.

Federal officials said yesterday that Congress had left it up to the nation's elderly, blind and disabled poor to decide what to do with the special grants they received this week to help pay increased winter heating costs. American Airlines said yesterday that on Tuesday one of its Boeing 707 jets nearly collided with a military helicopter over San Diego, a city that has become the focus of an intensifying dispute over air traffic rules.
Grain futures prices continued to slide on Middle Western grain exchanges yesterday, but not as low as many traders had predicted in the wake of dramatic price declines the day before.

EVERY once in a while we come across a restaurant that has a menu so large and so in triguing, we hate to finish reviewing it. A perfect case in point is the No. 1 Chinese Restaurant on Canal Street in Chinatown, for not even five visits seemed to provide an adequate sampling of this enormous menu. One always sees something enticing on a neighboring table, making "just one more" visit necessary.
EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J., Jan. 10 --A strike threatened for tomorrow night's opening of the Meadowlands harness track was averted when parimutuel clerks ratified a three-year contract tonight.

LUXEMBOURG, Jan. 10 (Reuters) --Common Market figures show industrial production in the European Economic Community grew 4 percent last year, well above the 2.4 percent increase in 1978, the community's statistics bureau said.

SINCE the 1980's have come, amid the trumpeting of countless newspaper and television features, can 1984 be far behind? In fact, the time for appraising George Orwell's prophetic novel is already here. Properly dated, 1980 is really 1984 because biblical scholars agree that, through a historical miscalculation, the Nativity actually occurred four years before the start of the Christian Era.

Some of the best bridge reading lies buried in past volumes of bridge magazines. Since very few enthusiasts have magazine collections, bound or unbound, the editors of The Bridge World, 39 West 94th Street New York, N.Y. 10025 have recently published a series of booklets containing outstanding past material, available for $3.50 each.

NBC announced yesterday that it had assembled a roster of 76 affiliates for its second radio network, called the Source, which is aimed at people in the age range of 18 to 34. Most of the programs--mainly brief newscasts--are tailored to stations with rock-music formats. All but a handful of the stations are on the FM band.

BANGKOK, Thailand, Jan. 10--Seventy Vietnamese refugees were slain by pirates off southern Thailand and the surviving women and girls raped repeatedly last Dec. 31, according to diplomats and officials of international relief organizations.
