The American Express Company acquired First Data Resources Inc., a Waltham, Mass.-based processor of credit and debit card transactions, for about $50 million in cash over the next four years, plus additional amounts based on future earnings, American Express said yesterday.

ARBOR HOUSE has secured the rights to publish in this country the account of a planned three-year, 52,000 mile voyage around the globe, by way of both poles, that was begun last September by a British expedition.

Joseph A. Lacqua, a waterfront businessman and former assistant district attorney in Brooklyn, was acquitted yesterday of a charge that he had made an illegal $3,000 payment to Anthony M. Scotto, a top leader of the International Longshoremen's Association.

The Commodity Exchange, the world's largest metals market, took further action yesterday to restrict trading in its booming silver futures trade. As of this morning, a limit of 50 contracts was placed on new purchases of futures maturing this month and next.

ALBANY, Jan. 10--A program for 100,000 state workers that rewards excellence on the job with $300 bonuses and career advancement has been suspended because too many employees have received high ratings from their supervisors.

DETROIT, Jan. 10 (AP)--Retail sales of United States-built trucks were down 17.3 percent in 1979 from the year before, but an industry association says the figures were the third highest ever despite the slump.
HONOLULU, Jan. 10 (AP)--A new winter storm lashed the Hawaiian Islands today with torrential rains, 60 miles per hour winds and huge waves on the south and west shores.

Three Federal prosecutors in New York and New Jersey, working with agents of an internal integrity unit of the United States Customs Service, are investigating widespread allegations of bribe-receiving, theft, fraud and smuggling on the part of high customs officials. The three-pronged inquiry, which has already led to several indictments and convictions, is expected to produce scores of cases when it is concluded.
In honor of Camilla Herrmann's 100th birthday, her cousin, Gerald Landman of Manhattan, has sent a $25 contribution to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

VANCOUVER, British Columbia, Jan. 10 (Reuters)--Kaiser Resources Ltd. said today that it had agreed to sell the business and assets of its asphalt paving and materials division to the Tanenbaum interests of Toronto for about $70 million (Canadian). The Canadian dollar is worth about 84 cents in United States currency.

BRASILIA, Jan. 10 (AP)-- Brazil has relinquished its development rights to huge oilfields it discovered in Iraq in return for a shipment of 11.3 million barrels of oil and other guarantees from the Arab nation, the Government has announced.

New York City officials are debating a cut of as much as $20 million in funds for the city's Department of Correction as part of an effort to close budget gaps over the next two years, according to sources close to the monthlong process.
ATLANTIC CITY--Leon Spinks is at the "crossroads" again, and this time Leon Spinks is "scared."
SUBSTANTIAL cost overruns and a half-year delay in the opening of Bally Manufacturing's Atlantic City casino have not cooled the com pany's enthusiasm for its new gambling hall and hotel.

LONDON, Jan. 10 (Reuters)--Leaders of the British Steel Corporation met today with officials of the Government's Advisory, Conciliation and Arbitration Service to discuss Britain's steel strike, now in its second week.
Vincent J. Manno, a nationally known newspaper broker and media financial consultant, died yesterday in Boca Raton, Fla., where he lived. He was 67 years old and formerly lived in New Canaan, Conn.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 10 (AP)-- United States businesses, apparently wary about the possibility of a recession, plan to restrain capital spending this year, the Commerce Department reported today.
ALBANY, Jan. 10--Paving the way for a floor vote on Monday, the Codes Committee of the Democratic-controlled Assembly reported out a bill today that would restore the death penalty in New York State.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 10--The State Department took issue today with an article in The New York Times reporting that President Carter had ordered the deferral of arms-control initiatives in talks with the Soviet Union.

TANANARIVE, Madagascar, Jan. 10 (Reuters)--Madagascar said today that it had discovered oil and gas and would become a net exporter by 1985. President Didier Ratsiraka, announcing the discovery in a speech, declined to give details on the size of the reserves or the likely rate of production. Madagascar currently imports 450,000 metric tons of oil a year from Iraq at a cost of about $65 million.

Charles Gounod is pretty much a one opera man, the opera in question being, of course, "Faust." But he composed many operas, oratorios and all kinds of music, and Friday night at the Hunter College Playhouse the Bronx Opera company put on a production of "Le Medicin malgre lui"--sung in English as "The Doctor Inspite of Himself." The little, charming work is based on :he Moliere comedy. It was first per formed in 1857 and was Gounod's first success. More of an operetta than an opera, it is extremely sophisticated harmonically for its day. It also carries the seeds of the more mature Gounod, and sections in it are direct anticipa tions of "Faust" (at one moment one expected the soprano to break into the "Jewel Song"). "Faust" reached the stage in 1859.

In 1972, Oregon became the first state to pass a bottle law. It was followed by Vermont, Maine, Michigan, Iowa and, after debate in seven legislative sessions, Connecticut. Delaware also passed a bottle law but with a sort of twist: It delayed implementation until neighboring Pennsylvania and Maryland adopt similar laws. Sullivan, executive director of the Connecticut Beer Wholesalers Association. But officials of the Coca-Cola Company said that, ounce for ounce, their soft drink will cost less in Connecticut in reusable bottles.

Unexpectedly, he was challenged by his own appointee, the majority lead er, Howard Berman of Los Angeles, who was backed by 27 of the 50 Demo crats in the 80-seat Assembly. But at midterm of a two-year session, 91 votes would be required to declare the Speakership vacant; Mr. Berman can not get that many votes without Re publican assistance and Mr. McCar thy so far is unwilling to yield to Mr. Berman's slim majority of the Demo cratic caucus.

TRONDHEIM, Norway, Jan. 19 (AP) -- By winning the opening 500 meter sprint in 38.76 seconds and plac ing fourth in the 5,000 race in 7 minutes 33.33 seconds, Kay Stenshjemmet of Norway took a narrow lead in the men s European speed skating cham pionships today. He collected 82.093 points. [Jan Egil Storholt] of Norway, the de fending champion, held second place with 82.568. Storhoit was second in both races with clockings of 39.26 and 7:13.08. Tomas Gustafson of Sweden was third with 82.842.

At the Southside Hospital at Bay Shore, L.L, a strike was narrowly averted Friday. Negotiators for the Nurses' As sociation and the hospital, with the assist ance of Hezekiah Brown, a Federal mediator, worked throughout the night Thursday and announced the settlement minutes before a walkout had been sched uled. Details of the pact were not made public, but a union source said the nurses would receive 30 percent in salary in creases and benefits over 26 months, rais ing salaries to about $17,000 by the end of the contract. The challenges to the previous domina tion of the Nurses' Association and the dissatisfaction of some nurses with their pay, hours and duties appear to have spurted the association to adopt a more aggressive role than in the past. But the challengers contend that the association has failed to work hard enough at improv ing salaries and working conditions.

At a union hall last weekend, Governor [Edmund G. Brown Jr.] under standably offered a withering glance to a fool s shouted question: "Where's Linda?" The subject of interest was Miss Ronstadt, his celebrity friend, not Jimmy Carter, the missing candidate who at chat hour was likely on the White House phone to another 20 Iowans. Here in Iowa, there is a loose overlay of TV commer cials, but the basic tactic is voter identification by tele phone. While Ronald Reagan gave only a modicum of visiting time to the state, his campaign organization had 50 telephones going into each night. The technique is to reach out through Republican voting lists, just say "Hi," and then quickly brain-pick the preferences of the persons called. Ones that come up Reagan or "maybe" then are put on new lists to be called and repeat edly toward the crucial step of getting them down to their neighborhood caucus. (Each party divides Iowa into 2,531 precincts in six Congressional districts; or, to put it an other way, in three area codes.) For the Democrats, Iowa was to be the exciting start of the long awaited candidacy of Senator Kennedy, bear ing the honored standard of his brothers in an insurgent challenge to the incumbent Mr. Carter. But as world crises intensified, driving Mr. Carter's once anemic lead ership rating up in the polls, the President stayed in Wash ington and cancelled a national television debate with Senator Kennedy and Governor Brown that had been scheduled for Jan. 7.

Gnosticism also figures here in talis mans and symbols of all kinds. The most engaging of them is the small fig ure of Satan with black face, horns, a tail and spindly legs. He wears a red dress with a fringe and holds out a bag from which money appears to be pour ing. Although Miss Hammond's de signs are all fascinating for the gamut of history they cover--from the "Star Spangled Pig of Troy" to the Aztec sign for gold, runes and the marks of medie val stonemasons and armorers to cat tle brands in Texas--she is most inter esting from the artistic point of view when working more realistically. Her most ambitious work, however, is in the large group of landscapes and seascapes and architectural views. Some of the most beautiful are scenes of New York City, particularly the ': small "Lonely Encounter" and "Growth of a Giant." The one shows a gray building with windows shadowed in black and in front of it a yellow bull-- ; dozer; the other deals with red scat folding being erected in front of fin ished buildings. The artist has not been greatly affected by Cubism, or for that matter, by Surrealism. One can tell, however, that she was around when these movements broke in the United States, whether by the whiff of Stuart Davis that emanates from the city ' scenes or from the de Chirico-like ef fect she achieves in works such as "Ruined Temple," two classical col--' umns in black casting shadows on a, desert under a blue sky.

The established magazines have been fervently rushing out their own specialized periodicals. McCall's has Working Mother, aimed at the 16 million mothers with jobs. Conde Nast has Self. Family Circle is contemplating putting out Women Who Work. Does this make sense to compete with yourself? "I think it behooves the publishers of existing magazines to produce these new special interest ones," says one magazine watcher. "If they don't, someone else will," "I think some new women s magazines will go by the boards, but I think the fallout rate will be lower than for magazines in general," he says. "That's because the maga zine market is primarily a women s market. I think that s because women aren't sitting around watching the Green Bay Packers and the Pittsburgh Steelers hour after hour practically around the calendar." Following the changes in the entire female population, just under half of Good Housekeeping's circulation now con sists of working women. "We respond to that no: by giving articles related to working women, but articles on how to manage the home with more limited time," Mr. [John Mack Carter] says. "We haven't changed the magazine to recognize the mind of the woman at the office."

The drawbacks are that the bases would be less under United States con trol, more subject to local political re strictions and less capable of serving the United States fleet, aircraft and ground forces since the logistic support provided would be much lighter than that of per manent American bases. The new concept for bases abroad dif fers markedly from that governing the spread of American bases around the world since World War II. Those bases were operated by the United States, with the Stars and Stripes atop the flagpole, an American commander in the headquar ters and a marine, soldier or airman guarding the gate. As needs, governments and circum stances have changed, the United States has lost bases in Spain, Libya, Saudi Ara bia, Pakistan, Vietnam and Japan, to name a few. Other facilities have been consolidated or put under greater restric tions.

SACRAMENTO, Calif., Jan. 19 (UPI) --California farmers and ranchers earned a nationwide high of $12 billion in farm income last year, the State Food and Agriculture Department reported yesterday. The department said farm earnings were up 16 percent over 1978 and production showed a 10 percent increase as California retained its long-time ranking as the nation's No. 1 farm state.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19 (AP)--Congressional auditors say that Federal agencies may spend close to $4 billion in the next decade buying private land but that the agencies do little planning and give little thought to whether the land is needed.

The manual--more than 500 pages -- is an 18th-century work called "al Amal al-Mutlaq." Its author, Al-Sijil masi, who died in 1800, was an eminent jurist-"the equivalent of a Talmudic scholar in Judaica," said Dr. [Henry Toledano]. "The book," he said, "is basically an anthology of judicial precedents which was designed to serve as a guide manual for future judges. It is very much like a book on case law in English and American law. It covers every thing-marriage and divorce, sale and related questions, conciliation, part nerships, torts, agency, contracts, re lease, pre-emption, rent, reward, char itable trusts, judicial procedure, and evidence and homicide, legacy and general questions." To those who wonder about the rele vance of a study of 18th-century Is lamic law in today s world, the profes sor has a ready reply. "Islamic society is, basically, a law-oriented society," he said. "One cannot understand Is lamic society without a good under standing of how Islamic law operates in the everyday life of the Muslims."

ELSINBORO, N.J., Jan. 19 (AP)-- After 28 years as the law in this tiny town, Chief William Venable, 62 years old, has been forced to hang up his pearl-handled pistol and watch his three-man Police Department be disbanded.

We have one last hope for Pran: [Jon Swain] happens to have a second British pass port. It is in Swain's name, but we think we can doctor it and alter the name skillfully enough to give Pran a foreign identity. Al Rockotf sets to work with a pen, a razor blade and some glue. Swain has two middle names, so by erasing "Jon" and "Swain," Pran has a new name. But It's a tongue twister-Ancketill Brewer and Pran spends hours trying to learn how to it and make it his own. We sub stitute Pran's photo for Swain's and the next day -- April 19--we turn the pass port in to the French with our own. A day later, the French come to Swain and tell him the ploy won t work; they say that the Khmer Rouge wiil spot the forgery as quickly as they did and that it could compromise the entire compound. They will kill him on the spot, the French say, and maybe us, too. They insist Pran has to leave. With their cruelty, the Khmer Rouge brought a new language words with a dehumanized ring, a me- chanical quality, - for atrocity, words that people had never heard before. There was the omnipresent Angka the word for the Khmer Rouge re- gime itself. It means simply "the or- ganization." No explanations were ever given for policy, just "Angha says" or "Angka orders." People were called , or "instru- ments." The Khmer nation was called Among the cables was one from Jon Swain, the British journalist whose life Pran had saved along with mine when we Were captured by the Khmer Rouge. It read: "Syd- ney, this is the mest wonder- ful, wonderful news. Please give Pran my love and a big hug from someone who owes him everything." Pran's reply to Jon read something like a Cambodian proverb: "Hi, 3on. The world is round. Now I meet you again. Pran was in bad shape, but the is re- mained Love, Pran."

"The trick is not so much inventing something as discovering the require ments," he said. "As I lay on the side of a cold mountain, my hands freezing, the requirements suddenly became clear: not only keeping the ski and the boot together, but getting them back to gether after a fall." "The whole history of the ski busi ness," said [Alex Eisemann], "is one prone to technological obsolescence. For in stance, it s taken five years or more for plastic boots to supplant leather. It took five years for metal skis to do away with wooden skis, and about the same length of time for aluminum poles to replace bamboo. "Bristol Mountain, for example, has gone 100 percent for Burt Bindings," Eisemann said, "because they re great for beginners and because they reduce accidents to a minimum and thus re duce liability insurance costs."

"Tevye" belongs to the small family of feature-length Yiddish films that en joyed a brief in the decade that ended with World War II. In the years that followed, these films--in cluding such classics of the Yiddish stage as "The ITybbuk," "Mirele Efros," "Uncle Moses," "Green Fields" and "The Yiddish King Lear" The Yiddish film "industry" that produced these movies in the 1930's was a slapdash affair that left no one rich but many people happy. Like Jonah's gourd that grew up in a night and per ished in a night, the making of Yiddish talking pictures began in New York in 1931 and ended in the early 40's after Hitler's invasion of eastern Europe. Ironically, in January 1940, just as this business was about to fade away, Vari ety ran an article under the headline "Negro and Yiddish Films Boom," de scribing production plans for a propor large number of Yiddish films '-- five--in the coming year. It was, in fact, a "boom" year for Yiddish films, but it was virtually the last, for the whole phenomenon of Yiddish films came slowly to a halt after the holo caust. In a single decade-from 1931 to 1991--about a hundred Yiddish lan guage feature films were made; and, of these, only 40 or 50 at most have sur vived. dish sound track. As for the technical problem of synchronizing the dubbing, Mr. Green shrugs It off. "We were guessing," he says, "but whatever came out was all right. Most of the ac tors had beards and you couldn't see their lip movements." Mr. Green's in genious gamble paid off. "Joseph in Egypt" was a hit in Poland and earned enough for him to be able to spend $80,000 financing his own film. "Yidel Mit a Fide!" (1935)-conceived and di rected by Mr. Green-established him as one of the leading figures in the pro duction of Yiddish sound movies.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19--President Aristides Royo has complained bitterly to President Carter that the American legis lation for carrying out the Panama Canal treaties violates the treaties and is "unacceptable in every way for the Re public of Panama." Meanwhile, however, Panama's Am bassador in Washington, Carlos Lopez Guevara, suggested in an interview with a Panamanian radio station that unless the United States took steps to "remedy the situation," Panama might renounce the canal treaties. Mr. Royo, then Minister of Education, was one of Panama's negotiators. Pana manian critics of the treaties have ac cused the negotiators of failing to stand up to the United States strongly enough.

"It's going out as scrap,and will be back as Toyotas and Datsuns," said a spokesman for the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey. The Fei Cui Hai brought no cargo to Port Newark. On Jan. 11, the Fei Cui Hai left New ark for Yokohama. Later that day, the Tian Hai, another bulk carrier from China, moved into the Port Newark pier where the Fei Cui Hai had been berthed--an indication, perhaps, that Mr. [Alan Sagner]'s mission is beginning to succeed.

These robes also demonstrate the theatrical flair of the Manchu people who had them elaborately embroidered so that they would add color and star tling glitter to the dimly lit halls of the palace. The robes are superbly hung on a Tinker-Toy-like framework designed by Cleo Nichols. All that is missing is seeing how the symbolism of each coat came alive when it was worn. For it was the Manchu belief that the human body became the axis of the world, and the wearer s head the apex of the uni verse. The bottom edge of the garment is invariably stitched with a rainbow of stripes or swirls depicting the ocean. Surprisingly, these splendid borders were all anyone saw of the richly orna mented robe worn at court. Surcoats -- dark, unbelted garments bearing the pictorial insignia of rank-became re quired attire in 1759, and these coats covered most of the ravishing robes fa vored by royalty and their followers. The show at Asia House includes ap proximately 25 garments, dating from the 18th century through about 1905. Glorious court robes dominate, in dy namic and subdued colors, emblazoned with dragons, flowers, ocean waves, mountains and rippling clouds. Most of these are 19th century, and more than a few are imperial. At least six reveal the taste of the Dowager Empress Tzuhsi, who favored bold turquoise and violet. These ravishing robes, which include an emperor s yellow coat dating to the turn of the 19th century, were selected by John Vollmer, associate curator in charge of the textile department at the Royal Ontario Museum, in order to ex plain the origins of both the construc tion of these garments and the tradi tional colors and motifs dramatizing their surfaces.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 19 (AP)--The United States Naval Academy has ended its nine-month investigation of student drug use with the expulsion of two more midshipmen and the resignation of a third. The action, taken earlier this week, brought to 16 the number of midshipmen dismissed from the academy as a result of the biggest marijuana case in school history.

Paul T. Rennell, a retired vice presi dent of Pan American World Airways, died yesterday at his home in Hobe Sound, Fla., after a long illness. He was 65 years old. Pravda said that soon after the Afghan Communist Party seized power in April 197S the Americans sought to use "interventionist forces" to "put an end to the revolution ary changes" and "throw the country back into the dark middle ages." The world s peoples, the paper said, have not forgotten that "mercenaries hired by the imperialist circles of the United States strangled the freedom of Guatemala," were thrown against "free dom-loving Cuba," crushed "democracy in Chile," tried to suppress the revolution in Vietnam before direct American inter vention and were "sent against the peo ples of nations in Africa."

Yet the discriminating reader of "The Gnostic Gospels" can learn, from material tucked away in the book, that the gnos tics' stance reflected neither a laudable democratic instinct nor an anticipation of women s liberation. The gnostics could share the highest clerical func tions among themselves be cause they regarded themselves as the elite and all other Chris tians as ignorant and (for some gnostics) as the massa ta. It would be a rare orthodox clergyman whose contempt for the laity would be comparable to the gnostic contempt for the non-gnostic. Similarly, the careful reader can discover that the gnostic texts that praise women do so because these women have re jected the "works of female ness." One of the most famous gnostic gospels ends with the principle that "Every woman who will make herself male will enter the kingdom of heaven." If some gnostic texts present Mary Magdalene as the great Christian spokesman--as against Peter, the hero of the or -it should not be forgot ten that men were probably the A final word on the greening of the gnostics by promoting this book through appeals to sex and daring. On the third page of her introduction, Professor [Elaine Pagels] quotes a passage that has [Jesus] kissing Mary Magda lene often on her mouth, and that passage is featured in ad for the book. It is only (air to warn the prurient that the action goes no further; this book, like the gnostic gos pels, rates a PG rather than an X. As for the hint that it would be daring to read such a hetero dox book, why not be more dar ing? Trust neither Professor Pageis nor her possibly suspect detractors, but instead buy the convenient collection of the gnostic works by 3ames M. Robinson. gust a year ago my wife and I moved to Westport from Freeport, L.I. Since I had served as a trustee of the Freeport Board of Education for 11 years, and my wife was extremely ac tive in school and community affairs, we began to inquire into the functions, activities and election of school board members. Not that I was interested in running (I was enjoying my free time after 11 years of service), but rather to learn how this community differed from Freeport. Witness what happened in Westport this year. Because Audrey Hansen did not vote the "party line," she was dumped. Fortunately, the electorate was alert to the problem and kept her on the board. I am not taking sides, but I am using this situation to document the reason why political parties should not be involved in school board mat ters. Individuals should run for the school board because they care about the education of the children, and can bring a particular point of view or ex pertise that will help provide a sound and effective educational program. Af filiation with a particular political party does not necessarily provide that input. Why can t we elect school board members in this state based upon their independent thinking rather than their party affiliations? During the 11 years of my tenure on the Freeport board, I was elected chairman on four different occasions without regard to my per sonal political associations. The board was composed of Republicans, Demo crats, Conservatives, Liberals and in dependents, and they cast their votes as free-thinking individuals with a re sponsibility to the children and the community. There was no bloc voting, no higher authority, no political party looking over shoulders.

As Mr. [Elie Massouda] spoke two elderly Karaites sitting in his office shook their heads in disagreement. One, Barouk Haroun, citing a story passed down through his family, said the Torah was brought by Jews to Cairo more than 700 years ago, during the Crusades. "This is true, this is true," murmured the other, Ibrahim Daoud Hosni, while Mr. Massouda said, "No, no, this is not true." "We do know that our Torah was written 12 centuries ago in the city of Tiberias by Ben Ashir, one of the fa mous leaders of the Karaites," Mr. Massouda said. "This is written in the front of the Torah, and it is also written that the Torah took 25 years to finish." He also rejected the assertion some times made by other Jews that the Kar aites are not Jews at all. "We are the real Jews," he said. "The difference between us and the others is the Tal mud, the book that they use to explain the Torah. We have only the Torah. We do not accept the Talmud."

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 19 (UPI)-- Julius Erving scored 24 points and Philadelphia fought off a late Cleve land rally as the 76ers defeated the Cavaliers, 111-107, tonight for their eighth straight National Basketball As sociation victory. The 76ers regained the lead on bas kets by Bobby Jones and Darryl Daw kins, and Erving's jump shot with 26 seconds remaining gave Philadelphia a 110-107 advantage. The Cavaliers then missed on two 3-point attempts, and Jones made a free throw with three sec onds left. The Pistons trailed by 97-90 early in the fourth quarter before [Bob McAdoo] and John Long scored 10 points each to rally the Pistons to their third straight victo ry. The three-game streak marks the Pistons' longest winning streak this season.

"The most likely ex planation is that the two strains are fective, but I am not sure the study says that other BCG strains necessarily are bad." The BCG bacillus was developed by Dr. Albert Calmette and Dr. Camille Guerin as an antituberculosis vaccine in 1921. The abbreviation stands for bacillus Cal mette-Guerin. The several BCG vaccines marketed around the world are derived from the original French vaccine. The two strains studied in India were pre pared in laboratories in France and Den mark and have been in use for many years. Health officials of some countries have asked American experts if BCG vaccina tion programs should be continued. Dr. [George W. Comstock] recommended that developing countries not abandon BCG; he believed there were some effective BCG vaccine strains.

Relations With Taiwan--The House defeated, 181-172, a proposal to estab lish an American "government liaison office" in Taiwan. The Administration was opposed to the amendment on the ground that it would constitute renewal of formal ties with Taiwan and violate Washington's new agreement with Pe king. Five Connecticut Representa tives agreed with the President; Mr. [Stewart B. McKinney] did not vote. Protecting Taiwan--The Senate re jected, 50 to 92, an amendment by Sena tor Charles H. Percy, Republican of Il linois, to declare that any hostile action against Taiwan would be considered a threat to the security interests of the United States. The President opposed the amendment. So did Mr. [Abraham A. Ribicoff]. But Mr. [Lowell P. Weicker] supported Senator Percy. Synthetic Fuels--The Senate went along with the President's plan for a multibillion-dollar investment in devel oping synthetic fuels such as liquids and gases made from coal and shale, approving a $20 billion program. A key vote came when an attempt was made to substitute a relatively modest $3 bil lion program supported by the Sierra Club among others. The President op posed the smaller program, but Sena tors Ribicoff and Weicker favored it. The Senate rejected the smaller pro gram, 57 to 37, and approved the $20 bil lion plan.

SALISBURY, Rhodesia--In three years of exile, Joshua Nkomo adopted the manner of the revolutionary, to the extent of acquiring a capacious general s uniform in East Germany. But when he finally came home last week, it was in the trappings of a peacemaker. Waving above the heads of the 150,000 supporters who flocked to cheer him were banners proclaiming "Nkomo for stability," "Nkomo for peace," "Nkomo for unity." The preference helps explain the heavy-handed policy that British colonial authorities in Rhodesia have adopted toward Mr. Nkomo's erstwhile partner in the guerrilla war, Robert Mugabe, who London fears might prove a practicing as well as a rhetorical Marxist in power. The British also doubt that Mr. Mugabe could survive the violent factional fighting that has characterized hls Zimbabwe African Na tional Union since it broke with Mr. Nkomo in 1963. Some officials in Salisbury argue that even a Mugabe abrogation of the truce would not torpedo the settlement, as long as Mr. Nkomo remained "on-side," as the Rhodesian parlance adopted by the British expresses it. If Mr. Mugabe pulled out, so the argument goes, he would be leaving the electoral field open to his rivals, primarily Mr. Nkomo and white Rhodesians' first black standard-bearer, Bishop Abel T. Muzorewa. The government that emerged, if it included Mr. Nkomo, would be assured of the backing of much of the world, presumably including the Soviet Union, Mr. Nkomo's principal backer in the war. China, Mr. Mugabe's main sup plier, would have the unenviable choice of accepting the new government or of supporting a continued insurgency with no certainty of success. The same considerations would apply for Tanzania and Mozambique, Mr. Mugabe's best African friends, with the added drawback that support for a pro tracted war would deny their battered economies the relief that peace in Rhodesia could bring.

Stigma Damages The 'Learning-Disabled' Unlikely? Unusual? Hardly. Ask anyone who works in a school providing special educational classes of any kind whether a similar incident has taken place this school year. T'he likelihood is that the answer will be "Yes." It doesn't matter whether the special classes are for the educable or trainable retarded, emotionally disturbed, neurologically impaired or learning disabled. The heightened interest in more effective education for the handicapped has been accompanied by-indeed may be a result of--vastly increased involvement of parents of handicapped youngsters. Such involvement has taken many forms, not the least of which is the many special parent teacher organizations that have sprung up throughout the state. These groups have been mast effective in focusing special attention on the needs of handicapped children, as witness the state-mandated requirements for due process, small class sizes, paraprofessional assistance and parent representation on committees on the handicapped. The com mittees largely control the evaluation, placement and con tinuous movement of handicapped students through the schools, and parents now play an important role in what used to be a more professionally controlled procedure.

HONG KONG, Jan. 19 (Reuters)-- Hong Kong has banned all hunting in an effort to preserve the little wildlife left in the tiny British colony. The Government said that none of its 414 game licenses would be renewed and that the use of guns will only be allowed in shooting clubs. Hong Kong has some wild duck and rabbits and a few wild boar and small deer near its border with China.

If you re a workaholic, you use time well, putting in long jam-packed days. "I'm no smarter than anybody else, I just need less sleep," said Robert Woodruff of Coca-Cola, with perhaps more modesty than honesty. Workaholics also do not draw lines or distinctions between business and pleasure. Sonny Werblin, current head of the Madison Square Garden Corpo ration, once lambasted a less-loyal as sociate: "You divide, you compart your life--I don't. It's one and the same with me." Employers, nevertheless, covet and collect workaholics, illustrated by the help-wanted ad that began, "We are looking for a competitive workaholic." Leo Miller, manager of the Polaroid Corporation's counseling department, concedes that companies welcome workaholics because "many of those who work hard also work well."

Most aroids contain toxic alkaloids, chemicals that may cause poisoning or at least severe irritation if eaten, and they should be kept out of reach of small children. Two species, however, produce staple food items in tropical regions where they abound. Elephant's ear, Calocasia esculenta, is the taro of the American tropics; the Polynesian poi is made from its starchy tubers. Ceriman, Monstera deliciosa, is best While the spathe of jack-in-the-pulpit is not brightly colored, many other spe cies of the family are known for their brightly colored spathes. The promi nent flowers of some have led to their being incorrectly called lilies. The calla lily, Zantedeschia , and the peace lily, Spathiphyllum clevelandii, are not lilies at all, but are aroids. Several species of Dieffenbachia are commonly grown. Each has a strong, upright cane that keeps growing taller with good care. Visitors should also look for the dealers' fairs that are being held more frequently all around the city. Fairs are springing up all over the country in the most unexpected loca tions to accommodate the great num ber of vendors. The Paris Foire a la [Ferraille] et aux Jambons (scrap metal and hams fair), the largest of its kind, held twice a year, was attended by 1,500 dealers last October at the Porte de la Villette. Less than a month later dealers flocked to an empty open-air swimming pool next to the Pont de la Concorde; recently they were in an abandoned railway station at the Bas tille. "We're trying to reach new cus tomers, people who d never cross town to go and hunt for curios," explained the organizers, Joel Garcia and Jean Marie Datin. "We're bringing fairs to their door, all around Paris." . . . to Puces de [Saint Ouen], take the metro to the Porte de Clignancourt, follow the Avenue de la Porte de Clignancourt until after the Peripher ique, turn left on the Rue des Rosiers out of which open the Marches Vernaison, Biron, Cambo, Malik, Serpette, Paul Bert. When you reach the Rue Paul Ben, turn left for the Marches des Ro- . siers, Paul Bert and Jules Valles. The Puces de Saint-Ouen is open Saturdays, Sundays and Mon days from 9 A.M. to 6 P.M. Best buys are early Saturday morning; many stalls are closed at lunchtime.

He constantly empha sized this universal, or not-necessarily American, focus of his first film in the United States. European directors come to America and want to make Westerns, Broadway plays, American things-even Milos Forman with 'Taking Off,' or Wertmuller or Malle. I don't. Bren nan Jr., using a reference to former Jus tice Abe Fortas, said: "From the begin ning of our association on the Court some 23 years ago I have believed with Mr. Jus tice Fortas that Mr. Justice Douglas is the only true genius I have ever known. President Mohammed Zia ul-Haq, who ousted Mr. [Zulfikar Ali Bhutto] in a coup d'etat in 1977, is a courtly professional army officer. He used to talk about "returning to the bar racks" and restoring civilian government within months, but has twice postponed parliamentary elections. Some, however, look to the discipline of this military regime as a gain sufficient to compensate for having lost the forms of democracy, especially since, under Mr. Bhutto, the forms were often misleading. Last week, General Zia conceded that he now expects the army to stay in power for "the next few years" at least. "Elections are not the remedy for Paki stan today," he said. "Seventy-five percent of the people of Pakistan are Illiterate. How do you expect illiterates to de cide for themselves what is good and what is bad for them?" Two years ago, General Zia said that he wanted to get the army out of government as quickly as possible--within months-because if it stayed in power too long it would "be come corrupted" and tarnish its international reputation. IVow, with soldiers making some decisions, even at local levels, under nonappealable martial law decree, some Pakistanis think that has happened. Aspiring to Islamic leadership, Pakistan has called an emergency meeting of Islamic Foreign Ministers here this month. After years of trying, it finally got into the non aligned movement last year, having abandoned the Western alliance that kept it out. "Now should we give it all up and go back into the pocket of the United States, especially if we consider America's aid to be both inadequate and nent?" the diplomat asked. "But of course nothing in this part of the world ever seems to be simple."

"I certainly don't see anything on the world scene that would encourage me to think defense budgets will be low ered," said Laurence J. Adams, presi dent of the Martin Marietta Aerospace Company. "Quite the opposite." Con sider these developments: "I would guess that since the start of the year, stocks of the major defense contractors have gone up 15 to 20 per cent, on top of a similar amount during the last few weeks of 1979 after the Em bassy seizure in Iran," said Wolfgang H. Demisch, aerospace industry ana lyst at Smith Barney Harris Upham Company. "The investment com munity is aware that the world is becoming a nastier place and that it s likely to be more fragmented and hos tile in the 1980's. That combination makes a helpful environment for mili tary contractors." General Dynamics, Lockheed, Litton Industries and the Ogden Corporation all own shipyards, and all are likely to benefit from President [Carter]'s goal of increasing the fleet from fewer than 400 ships to 550 in the 1990's. The new budget is expected to include $1.7 bil lion for two destroyers equipped with the Aegis antiaircraft system, and it likely will contain appropriations for defense against the large Soviet sub marine fleet--everything from a nu clear submarine that stalks enemy subs (built by General Dynamics) to antisubmarine warfare planes such as the Lockheed P-3 Neptune, used also by Canada, Japan, Australia, New Zea land and Iran.

If you cannot find the beams be cause the ceiling is finished, or it the beams are not situated where the verti cal two-by-fours must stand, then you can secure them by screwing metal braces or angle brackets to the upper end. The other leg of each bracket is then fastened to the ceiling with expan sion anchors or toggle-type fasteners. When a table lamp or floor lamp tends to flicker every time it is moved or tilted, or if the bulb doesn't light even though you know it is O.K, and the switch is on, very often the trouble is in side the socket into which the bulb screws. After unplugging the lamp cord, remove the bulb and look inside the empty socket. At the bottom you will see a small piece of springy metal that is supposed to press up against the bottom of the bulb to make electrical contact with the center of the bulb s base. sometimes this piece of metal gets coated with din or corro sion, and sometimes it loses some of its springiness and gets pressed down so that it no longer makes firm contact with the bottom of the bulb, even when the bulb is screwed down tight. Use the end of a small screwdriver to scrape the metal clean if it looks dirty. Also, make certain it is bent up the way it should be to make firm contact with the bottom of the bulb by prying it up care fully to bend it to a more upright posi tion. In many cases this is all that will be needed to eliminate flickering and make the lamp work properly again.

does the memory of the room in which they furtively met and loved summon up yearnings worth elaborating into fan rhythms. "You never thought of it as any kind of house, did you?" "I thought of it as a flat." That "flat" is flat in deed, as nouns and verbs march single-file into the empty afternoon. cept the growing tension, though. It is perfectly possible for Miss [Blythe Danner] and Mr. [Roy Scheider] to segue from silkily vi cious banter-the humor is in the ness, the rest of it is lethal--into an unexpected flareup of anguish. Midway through the reverse journey, with jeal still reigning all 'round, the three contenders are together briefly, briefly and civilly. Taking his leave, Mr. [Raul Julia] gives Miss Danner a suitably chaste so cial kiss-on the cheek. With the inter loper gone, Mr. Scheider compulsively strides directly to Miss Danner, takes her in his arms, kisses her passionate ly. It is a form of upmanship; we are a little inclined to laugh. But not for long, because the kiss becomes only half a kiss; there is oNy half a passion to sus tain it. Abruptly, Miss banner s head drops onto Mr. Scheider's shoulder, al most as though a guillotine had severed it from her clinging body; she is sob bing helplessly. We are always reading of "muffled sobs" without ever really hearing any. Miss banner produces the By the time "Betrayal" has arrived at its final scene, which is also its first scene, it has acquired overtone upon overtone. The past has absorbed the fu ture, making a bold musical chord of it: we hear all the notes at once. Lan guage has followed suit. We are no longer listening to that one-fingered ex ercise but to Mr. Julia, surprising Miss banner in the half-light of her bed room, breathlessly exclaiming "All these words I'm using--don't you see they ve never been used before?" The author s tricky, dramatically curved counterpoint is still very much with us as well. Mr. Julia to Miss banner: "You're so beautiful--look at the way you look at me!"

When the nuclear powered carrier Nimitz, for example, was ordered into the Indian Ocean earlier this month, it was rated by the Navy as having severe personnel shortages and mechanical problems. The Navy is said to have 25 ships in the Indian Ocean now, including three carri ers: the Nimitz, the Kitty Hawk and the Midway. Both the Midway and the Kitty Hawk are over 20 years old, and a naval analyst said the ships had mechanical problems because "they are being pushed to the point of exhaustion." Meanwhile, supplying the three carri ers and their escort vessels in the Indian Ocean from the Navy's base in the Philip pines was said by a Pentagon aide to have created "a logistical nightmare."

Almost none of them seemed to know why he wanted to be President. The exception was John Kennedy who, when asked, would reply, but only in private, "Because that s where the power is." All of them, of course, had some sort of public explanation calcu lated to mask their internal power drives under a gauze of clich s about their obligations to serve the Republic. The most sensible explana tion might be phrased this way: "My business is politics, the Presidency is the top job in politics, and like everybody else, 1'd like to have the top job." The reasons for the Presi dential lust are probably as di verse and mysterious as the psyches of the candidates, and if the truth were told it would more often than not doubtless leave the voters agape with consternation. "The Federal Government is willing to spend millions of dollars to clone the Mississippi River," he went on, questioning a plan to construct a parallel waterway and asking, "What's wrong with the Mississippi7" New York's Governor Carey is supporting the Do -[Daniel Patrick Moynihan] approach, as are the Governors of 'Hawaii, California, Michigan, Virginia, Oregon, Utah, Massachusetts and Connecticut. Its compan ion measure has been introduced in the House of Rep resentatives by Jerome A. Ambro of Long Island and has 15 co-sponsors, mostly New Yorkers, but also in cluding Representative James C. Cleveland, Repub lican of New Hampshire, who is a high-ranking mi nority member of the Public Works and Transporta tion Committee. Since Mr. Ambro ranks high in the Democratic majority of that committee, the Ambro Cleveland combination would seem to enhance the prospects of the bill reaching the House floor if the Senate acted favorably on it. It also would provide millions in New York to com bat beach erosion on Coney Island and in Connecticut for flood control in the Mamaroneck and Sheldrake River Basins and the Byram River. But Senator Moynihan wants to provide for such a huge project as New York City's third water tunnel, some thing that probably would not get funds under the present system. The tunnel vas under construction from 1970 until 1975, when the city s fiscal crisis forced a halt in work on it. A total of $350 million has been spent on the tunnel, which is to stretch someday for 12.7 miles from the Hillview Reservoir in Yonkers and supply all five boroughs. It has been dogged by delays and litigation, with six contractors suing the city last year for work that they said they had not been paid for. They sued for $100 million and settled for $18 million. The House of Representatives is to vote this week on the Rivers and Harbors Act, which also contains provision for a $25 million loan for the water tunnel. The city would like to get the loan, of course; it would prefer the approach in the [Domenici]-Moynihan measure.

Mr. [Nikolaus Harnoncourt]'s latest ministra tions on behalf of [Handel-Bach] have born fruit in a recording of his last oratorio, "Jephtha." Handel's eyesight tailed him during the composition of this li --ironically while he was writ ing the great chorus that begins "How dark, 0 Lord, are Thy decrees! All hid from mortal sight." The story of Jeph tha, who must sacrifice his daughter to the gods, drew an , con score from the composer, More than Vivaldi and Handel, Bach is the provenance of all musicians, the internationally glamorous superstar as well as the Baroque specialist. This makes for an even wider range of inter possibilities, as witness the gulf that separates Herbert von Karajan's way with Bach's Magnificat and the latest two volumes in the Concentus Musicus/Leonhardt Consort's ongoing series of the complete cantatas. Military serv- ice, "which had emerged as a popular choice of graduating seniors in the late 1950's," was still attracting 17.5 percent of the class of 1960." Draft calls de creased steadily from 1970 to 1973, when the draft ended. The number of students entering military service decreased sharply after that, the report said, and has remained "essentially zero" since 1972.

If you cannot find the beams be cause the ceiling is finished, or if the beams are not situated where the verti cal two-by-fours must stand, then you can secure them by screwing metal braces or angle brackets to the upper end. When a table lamp or floor lamp tends to flicker every time it is moved or tilted, or if the bulb doesn't light even though you know it is O.K. and the switch is on, very often the trouble is in side the socket into which the bulb screws. After unplugging the lamp cord, remove the bulb and look inside the empty socket. At the bottom you will see a small piece of springy metal that is supposed to press up against the bottom of the bulb to make electrical contact with the center of the bulb s base. sometimes this piece of metal gets coated with dirt or corro sion, and sometimes it loses some of its springiness and gets pressed down so that it no longer makes firm contact with the bottom of the bulb, even when the bulb is screwed down tight. Use the end of a small screwdriver to scrape the metal clean if it looks dirty. Also, make certain it is bent up the way it should be to make firm contact with the bottom of the bulb by prying it up care fully to bend it to a more upright posi tion. In many cases this is all that will be needed to eliminate flickering and make the lamp work properly again.

All this is not to say that you cannot eat well and happily at The Copper Beech, but we would suggest veering toward the less complicated items on the menu. Among the pleasing choices were two deli cious appetizers--four piping hot and tender clams served in shell, topped with a light, crispy hazelnut dressing, and crepe au saumon, an elongated and delicate crepe filled with salmon, topped with a mildly piquant hollandaise sauce. (That same eve ning, though, a side order of cauliflower with hollan daise arrived overcooked, with a watery, ble sauce.) Alas, this one cannot. The Copper Beech's main weakness is that the menu promises more than it can deliver. A smaller menu, more carefully attended to, would produce subtler and happier results. There is also a tendency to excess, to showing off. Poached leeks vinaigrette with Roquefort topping would be a lovely dish without topping. The dressing is an un necessary addition to the light lacing of the vinai grette. A hearty and robust pate of wild rabbit, served from an attractive rabbit-shaped ceramic terrine, was excellent in and of itself. It did not bene fit from the bland puree-like pumpkin sauce that ac companied it. calf sweetbreads were lightly done and delicious. Being served in a bready, charac brioche did nothing to enhance an already

My money swindles along with my self-esteem. I'm beginning to consider myself a fool when I think in terms of the old adage, "A fool and his money are soon parted." I will put in a goodly supply of books, chosen not for literary quality. They can be rated "hot stuff"; their locales must be close to the equator. There should be more warmth from my reading lamp than from the radiator. Dante's "Inferno" and "Cat on a Hot Tin Roof" will have a prominent place on my bookshelf. Poor Jack London will be relegated to the rear. Likewise, my choice of television programs will be influenced by the same need to think warm thoughts. The usual loathed commercials may even win my tepid approval. Under igloo conditions, viewing the "Come to Jamaica" bit could be fun. If Gloria Van derbilt were to do denim short shorts in Florida pas tels, my blood heat would react favorably.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 19--"I love New York," Senator William Proxmire said. "It's a terrific city--maybe the only true international city in the world--but I do think that they ve lacked discipline and wasted money." Senator Proxmire declined to comment when the Mayor released his plan. He waited, instead, until it could be studied and, like a teacher, awarded the city the grade of "a provisional `A' ",with the inducement that he would increase the grade to "an unqualified 'A' " if the Mayor fulfilled his pledges. Although he used such words as "blame" and said that New York officials "have got some pretty tough answers to come up with" at the hearings on Jan. 28 and 29, the Senator insisted that he was not prejudging the situation. "Trial first, verdict later," he said with a grin.

9Most access roads to a Bayville Rye bridge are already built. A major part of the cost of bridge construction is the cost of getting traffic quickly and safely onto and off the bridge. A Bay ville-Rye bridge could be linked quickly and economically to the Sea ford-Oyster Bay Expressway, which now ends at Jericho Turnpike (the state already owns most of the right-of way north to the Sound), and to the Cross-Westchester Expressway and the New England Thruway. In West chester the distance to the hookup is less than a mile. In contrast, the pro posed bridges farther east lack mod ern, safe, high-speed access routes. Even the Wading River site comes up short in this respect. The William Floyd Parkway can hardly be consid ered a limited-access highway. 9It is where the traffic volume is. Estimates are that there would be three times as much traffic around the Bayville terminus as around Port Jef ferson, the nearest proposed bridge ter minus to the east. Estimates are that 85 percent of the traffic needed to sustain a cross-Sound bridge from Bayville to Rye is already there. And, studies show, Whitestone and Throgs Neck Bridge traffic right now is primarily not New York City-oriented; it is Nas sau, Suffolk, Westchester and western Connecticut traffic headed across the Sound by way of this long detour--a detour that puts motorists on roads that are among the most congested in the nation.

ATLANTA, Jan. 19 (AP)--The human life span has increased dramatically in the 20th century because of the spectacular success of disease control, but the next 20 years will likely bring little improvement, says an assistant director of the national Center for Disease Control. The reason is that today's top killers are not infectious diseases but accidents, violence and chronic illnesses.

EAST HAMPTON THE sacred art of India is famil iar and popular here in the West, finding an audience even among those who have no un derstanding of its religious symbolism and function. The sheer beauty of the traditional bronzes, stone carvings and painted miniatures is in itself sufficient recommendation, but it should be remembered that these works are expressions not of individual creativity, but of faith.

"People have tried women s libera tion and it has broken their mar ," Mr. Fritjofson said. "Male chauvinism can do the same. The ex pectations of the macho, egocentric male and the woman liberationist clash." The wife of a happy husband, Mr. Fritjofson said, will fulfill his seven basic needs: She will respect his manli ness, accept him as her leader, reflect his tastes and standards in her dress and personal appearance, appeal to him when he attempts to go beyond his limitations, defend him against those who question him, allow him time "alone with himself and with the Lord," and express gratitude to him and praise his accomplishments. Fi nally, a wife should be "praised by other people for her character and her good works." "I think every wife can benefit from it," Juanita Poller of Miller Place said of the series for women. "It can take the tension out of marriage. I don't think women s lib is right. I don't think I have to be liberated from anything."

The academy report, "Energy in Transition," seemed a fitting addition to an unplanned trio, coming as it did on the heels of "Energy Future," the popular, conservation-ori ented book by seven faculty members of the Harvard Busi ness School, plus a pair of like-minded studies by Resources for the Future, a Washington think tank. Nonetheless, gains from energy efficiency have proved highly rewarding, say its advocates. Without this surprise element, they point out, the country would be importing 50 percent more oit than it is now doing. Indeed, greater energy efficiency has been by far the most helpful factor in the mix of supply and demand responses that have come about since the Arab oil embargo six years ago. "We have gotten more energy from efficiency improvements than from any form of supply--including oil imports," says Lee Schipper, a staff scientist at Lawrence Berkeley Laboratory and a con tributor to the National Academy of Science study. "The continuation of artificially low prices would tably widen the gap between domestic supply and demand, and this could only be made up [by] increased imports, a policy that would be increasingly hazardous and difficult to sustain," the National Academy of Science study warns. "Indeed," its authors add, "as energy prices rise, the nation will face important losses in economic growth if we do not significantly increase the economy s energy efficiency." They also say the Government should continue passing regulations, standards and incentives when necessary to as sist the "invisible hand" of the marketplace.

PANAMA, Jan. 19 (AP)--A bus carrying newly certified forest rangers veered out of control yesterday and plunged into a gorge, killing four persons and injuring 56, authorities said today. Investigators said the accident in Veraguas Province, about 170 miles west of here, was under investigation.

The [Daniel P. Davison] family has "been wage slaves for the Morgans for years," the head of the Trust Company said jokingly in an interview last week. Mr. Davison, 54, joined the Trust Company last May after having lost the bid for the top job at the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company, where he was executive vice president. He is considered "a bit of a patrician" even by some of his former associates at Morgan. Patrician or not, Mr. Davison is affable and forthcoming when he meets visitors. He eschews the tough "macho style" speech and crisp pin-stripe suits that have become chic among top bank managers. Mr. Davison wears comfort able suits, often brawn, and loafers. "The place was overloaded with costs," says Mr. Davison, acknowledging that so far he has hardly scratched the surface. "We spent between $15,000 and $2D,000 a year on flowers," he said. "That's half a-cent a share."

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 19-- Eighteen of the world-class athletes who competed in or watched last night's Philadelphia Track Classic signed a petition urging the Federal Government to support a change in venue for the Olympic Games, scheduled next summer in Moscow.

ALBERTSON PART-skim, low-fat, salt-free, low-cholesterol and low-calorie are terms that consumers encounter with increasing fre quency when shopping for cheese. According to Alan Eisen, who with his wife, Ruth, owns the Cheese Gallery in Albertson, the average consumer's general understanding of these terms as they relate to cheese and diet is poor.

Wintertime on Nantucket can be like stepping into a Currier and Ives paint ing. Around the holiday season, the im pression is vivid, as garlands, ribbons and pine boughs make shop windows merry; cranberry and evergreen wreaths decorate island doorways. Shopkeepers welcome visitors with cups of wassail or steaming hot toddy, and some of Nantucket's craftspeople have their work on display. A hundred lighted trees (each covered with hand made ornaments) line the cobblestoned main street; the songs of carollers ring. mation center at 25 Federal Street. Nearby you will find the Peter Folger Museum, which houses a collection of Nantucket memorabilia. The Whaling Museum is next door and children will delight in seeing the skeleton of a 94 foot whale. You can also find some fine examples of old scrimshaw and, if you like, purchase a pendant made by one of Nantucket's contemporary scrims handers. Finding good food is never a prob lem. The Boarding House has long been a popular place to have a leisurely lunch or to enjoy a fancy dinner in the dining room upstairs. The Thistle pro vides a comfortable tearoom atmos phere. In this restored historic house you might lunch on homemade soup, fresh oatmeal or onion dill bread, a salad and a glass of wine. The dinner menu offers international cuisine and Nantucket seafood at reasonable prices. A bountiful breakfast may be taken at the India House; year round the family might like the Mad Hatter's extensive menu. The tap room of the Jared Coffin House provides entertain ment at mealtime. If you like jazz, stop in for a drink and entertainment at the Rose and Crown. The Atlantic Caf is a lively, spacious bar where many is landers share an after-work drink or light supper. Meals, which may cost $25 or more a person during the summer months, are somewhat less in the win ter. A list of eating places and their winter hours is available at the infor mation center.

SAN LORENZO DEL ESCORIAL, Spain, Jan. 19--With military pomp and solemn pageantry, the remains of King Alfonso XIII, who abandoned his throne and nation in 1931 and died in exile in Rome, were returned to Spain today to be interred with past monarchs in the monastery of El Escorial.

"Last fall, I couldn't find anyone who was openly for Carter, and now it s turned around completely," said one Democratic politician, with long ties to the Kennedy family, who still backs the Senator but is worried about the outlook. "If the election were held in Illinois today, Carter would win." "Right now, it s Carter's lead t.o blow," said Mr. [Roman Pucinski], who has broken with the Cook County party organization and put his daughter on a pro-Carter slate. Without doing better than expected in Iowa and elsewhere, Mr. Pucinski said, "I doubt Kennedy can turn it around here in Illinois in just eight weeks."

NEWARK, Jan. 19 (AP)--Five men charged with trying to defraud buyers of land in a Pocono Mountains resort were acquitted today.

a little differently again. Nothing radical though. "Gimmicks," says [Bud Carson], "aren't going to beat them." But a few little surprises could. Bud Carson enjoys surprising other teams. Three weeks ago he de vised a defense with seven defensive backs that unloaded the Dallas Cow boys' shotgun formation in the play offs, a reminder of why Bud Carson is considered one of the National Football League's most respected defensive geniuses. "In an obvious passing situation," Bud Carson says, "we can get a fifth defensive back in there who will give us double coverage on both wide re ceivers. And against [Terry Bradshaw], you need that. I think Bradshaw is the best quarterback there is. Nobody has an arm like he has. And if he s running around, he s hard to bring down. He shakes off linebackers. He doesn't always scramble for yard age. He mostly buys time to throw. But he s likely to run a lot more in a Super Bowl game because the season is all over. They'll turn him loose." "For this game," [Lionel Taylor] says of the Super Bowl, "the thing I've tried to impress on my receivers is, each second expect to get hit be cause the Steelers hit people hard. But our defensive backs have been asking me about [Lynn Swann] and Stall worth, who I had for four seasons. I just remind them how high Swann can leap and that [John Stallworth] is tough to bring down. You can t one-arm him."

Spectacular Bid easily fought off a stretch challenge by Flying Palter and captured the $108,300 San Fernando Stakes by one and a half lengths. The $63,30D purse brought the 4-year-old gray horse s earnings to $1,774,917, which moved him past Round 'fable and into fourth place on throughbred racing s career list. "I wasn't worried," he said. "No horse has ever passed Bid in the stretch except in the Belmont Stakes. Passer's a hell of a horse, he could beat any other horse in America, but he can never beat Bid." Finally, the crisis crisis. When the Korean War needed a name, it was officially clubbed "the Korean Conflict" by a Congress which had never declared it a war. The events in Iran are called "the Iranian crisis." But a crisis--from the Greek "to separate" -- is a decisive moment, or turning point requiring quick resolu tion. A "chronic crisis" is a contradiction in terms. "Af fair" is not somber enough, and "matter" is weak; Russell Baker alluded to "situation" by writing of deliberations in the "White House Stalemate Room." Easy. "Cannot help but" confuses two different idioms: "I cannot but do it," and "I cannot help doing it." In the first, the "but" means "other than" -- "I cannot but do it" means "I cannot do other wise." In the second, the "help" means "help myself from," or "stop myself" -- thus, "I cannot help doing it" means "I cannot stop myself from doing it." "The New York Times Com pany named Walter Mattson as president," wrote The Wall Street Journal, "succeeding Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, who remains as chairman." Nei ther "as" is needed (though both men are needed, desper ately). Later in the same story, the "as" is dropped: "He also was named chief op erating officer." We do not need "as" following designat ing verbs--"appointed," "anointed," "designated," "named" -- any more than we need "to be" following choice verbs--"picked," "chosen," "elected," "selected." Cross 'em out, they clutter up sen .

It is precisely circuslike icing on an impeccably re- cake that has made the Winter Antiques Show, held annually for 26 years at the Seventh Regiment Armory on Park Avenue at 67th Street, a smash success m recent years. Yet, a mere five years ago, the show was a staid af- fair, which netted its organiz- ers and beneficiary, The East Side House Settlement, only $31,000. "The opening-night patrons' party catered to an elite group of collectors," Marlo Buatta says. "By 8:30 a cannon shot off in the center aisle wouldn't have hit a soul. Naturally, there was talk of discontinuing the show." Naturally, booths at this invitational event are highly coveted. One dis- tinguished dealer who, years ago, declined an in- to participate ad- mits that now a platoon of perennials would have to die before he could get an- other chance. But other nonparticipating dealers aren't certain it s worth all the fuss. "It's a pretty show," one admits, "but I can t remember a single stupendous commode, or a wonderful pair of chairs. There are a few good deal- ers out so many are provincial. Painted coun- try things can be charm- ing, but I don't think they belong with truly fine an- tiques." Visitors to this year s Winter Antiques Show should not count on reasonable prices. An- tiques have entered the inflationary spiral. Those collectors who are in it for the investment will - tably wonder, "To buy or not to buy?" -- a question that haunts dealers, too. "When I see the prices," says dealer Ed Clerk, "I think, 'This is outrageous; the market has peaked.' Yet, in all my years in the business, I've never re- spending too much. All my sorrows have been over the things I wanted but didn't buy."
Two Republican district leaders on the East Side are trying to deny Vincent F. Albano Jr., New York State's senior Republican county leader, a delegate's role at the Republican National Convention.

As the United States took over the strategic role of the European powers, it assumed their tutelary role as well. In return for economic concessions, diplomatic and sometimes military support, it shored up these elites and protected them from internal and ex ternal enemies. Some of these elites those of Chiang Kai-shek, King Farauk of Egypt, and the Emperor Bao Dai of Vietnam--succumbed fairly quickly to revolutions or military coups; a very few found constitutional means to share power; the rest hung on, at tempting at once to consolidate their power and increase it by the work of "modernization." For this latter group, the most faithful "allies" of the United States, there was a contradiction involved: "Modernization" -- whether it meant the building of roads or factories or a really efficient secret police--inevita bly cut into the social fabric that sup ported them. The peasants, who had The revolutions of the 70's have disor dered the world and created conditions for a new and more dangerous struggle between the superpowers. That the United States cannot control the world does not mean that the Soviet Union can. The Russians have not succeeded in dominating any country they have not occupied by military force. The in of Afghanistan is but another proof of their failure. That invasion, fur thermore, signals a turning point in the ideological competition, for with the General Assembly vote that "strongly deplored" the intervention and called for withdrawal, the third world has demonstrated that it no longer consid ers the Soviet Union the "natural ally" of revolutionary regimes.

THE aroid or arum family of plants is one of considerable interest to horticulturalists. While most of its members are of tropical origin, two species are among the better known wildflowers of the Northeast.

"Brandreth worked as a clockmaker in Middleswich, England, during the years 1760 to 1785," Mr. [Allan Dorfman] said. "In those days, different pans of a clock were often made by different townspeople. Someone made the hands, another the face and still an other the case. In this instance, the works are Brandreth's." "It's of oak, with a great deal of carv ing all over and a carving of St. George and the dragon at the waist. It's seven and a half feet tall, has a spit, or sec ond, hand and a calendar box to show the day. I'm asking $4,300 for it. It's all original and fully restored." Mr. Dorfman also will show a three piece mantel set from France-a clock and two candelabra--that dates to about 1885. The works are signed "Japy Silver Medal of Honor Win ner."

I DO not share the view of the coalition of state educational associations, which is opposed to the classification of our public schools as approved, approved with conditions or unapproved. I believe that classification is an essential part of an effective evaluation process and that it will serve as an incentive to force change where change is sorely needed.

FOR a French restaurant, La Mansarde in Amityville has a very unusual menu. It reads more like a Chinese restaurant menu, with listings between its vinyl covers that go on for pages and pages of complete dinners, gourmet din nets for two, a la carte entrees, dishes for two and long, self-serving prefatory explanations.

WHEN Howie Schultz rejoined his family one Monday morning, no one was quite sure at first just who he was. His eyes red-rimmed with fatigue, his feet slightly unsure, his back bent from long hours of sitting, he stumbled forth.

Seems I can't keep away from chamber music in this column. Take a look at some of this week's events in New York. On Thursday, Emanuel Ax will play Schubert with the Vermeer Quartet at the Metropolitan Museum. On Friday, in Fisher Hall, three redoubtable soloists will combine forces: Vladimir Ashkenazy, Itzhak Perlman and Lynn Harrell.

VILLA SAN GIOVANNI, Italy, Jan. 19 (UPI)--The 31,680-ton Italian freighter Maria Speranza F and the 10,817-ton West German freighter Bavaria collided in the Strait of Messina between Sicily and the mainland today, slightly damaging both vessels.

In 1973, the Supreme Court legalized abortions, touching off a bitter national debate. In 1976, when Representative Henry Hyde got into the act, the debate became almost venomous. He wrote laws denying health-care funds to poor women who wanted to assert their right. Now, at last, a Federal judge has appraised this punitive social policy--and struck it down.

As a southbound BMT train crossed the Manhattan Bridge at 12:45 A.M. yesterday, five young muggers trapped two passengers between the first and second cars, assaulted them and threatened to hurl them off the train.
ALBANY, Jan. 18 Governor Carey and his aides have been hinting that the budget to be presented to the Legislature on Tuesday will fall short of Mayor Koch's expectations for state aid.

BAGHDAD, Iraq, Jan. 20 Iraq will maintain its current high level of oil production this year to help developing countries, not to make up for the decline in Iranian production, senior officials in the oil ministry have disclosed.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 Sanford M. Litvack, a 43 year-old New York corporation lawyer who calls himself "a pretty aggressive guy," has been installed as the Justice Department's new antitrust chief at a time when antitrust policy has come under sharp Congressional criticism.
